title: boeing ceo sacked payout compensation 737 max dennis muilenburg
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Departed CEO&nbsppreviously said he would forgo compensation until the&nbsp737 Max had fully returned to serviceDennis Muilenburg, who was ousted as Boeing’s chief executive last month as the company contended with the biggest crisis in its history, will depart with more than $60m&nbsp(£45m), the company said Friday.Mr Muilenburg will not receive any additional severance or separation payments in connection with his departure, and Boeing said he had forfeited stock units worth some $14.6m (£11.2m).But the value of the other stock and pension awards he is contractually entitled to receive is $62.2m (£47.6m), the company said. Mr&nbspMuilenburg also has stock options that could be worth many millions more.Sharing the full story, not just the headlines“We thank Dennis for his nearly 35 years of service to the Boeing Company,” the company said in a statement. “Upon his departure, Dennis received the benefits to which he was contractually entitled and he did not receive any severance pay or a 2019 annual bonus.”Boeing’s new chief executive, David Calhoun, will receive a $7m (£5.3m)&nbspbonus if he is able to get the 737 Max, which has been grounded since March, safely flying again. The jet was grounded in the wake of two deadly crashes that left 346 people dead.Created with Sketch.Boeing parks grounded 737 planes in employee car park: In pictures Show all 6Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Boeing 737 aeroplanes are parked in the employee car park of Boeing's Seattle factory Seen above the car park is the full storage area for planes at Boeing's Seattle factorySix 737s are currently being stored in the car park as they have not been delivered from the factory due to the model being grounded following two major crashesBoeing has incurred first quarter losses of around $1 billion following the crashes and ensuing controversyThe company grounded their 737 model in March following their second deadly crash in monthsSeen above the car park is the full storage area for planes at Boeing's Seattle factoryBoeing 737 aeroplanes are parked in the employee car park of Boeing's Seattle factory Seen above the car park is the full storage area for planes at Boeing's Seattle factorySix 737s are currently being stored in the car park as they have not been delivered from the factory due to the model being grounded following two major crashesBoeing has incurred first quarter losses of around $1 billion following the crashes and ensuing controversyThe company grounded their 737 model in March following their second deadly crash in monthsSeen above the car park is the full storage area for planes at Boeing's Seattle factoryThe issue of Mr Muilenburg’s compensation was the source of heated exchanges during his testimony before congress in October.“Are you taking a cut in pay? Are you working for free from now on until you can cure this problem?” Representative Stephen Cohen&nbspasked Mr Muilenburg at one point. “These people’s relatives are not coming back. They’re gone. Your salary is still on.”Mr Muilenburg went pale, noting that the board determines his pay.After the hearings, Mr Muilenburg called Mr Calhoun, then the Boeing chair, and offered to forgo any compensation until the Max had fully returned to service. Speaking at a New York Times conference soon after that, Mr Muilenburg said he decided to give up “tens of millions of dollars” after meeting with families of victims of the crashes.How can I make sure I avoid the Boeing 737 Max?“I felt it was important for me to forgo those bonuses and send a message of responsibility,” he said.Boeing said Mr Calhoun, who starts as chief executive Monday, would receive a base salary of $1.4m (£1m) and be eligible for an annual target bonus of $2.5m (£1.9m), long-term incentive awards worth $7.5m (£5.7m) and restricted stock units worth $10m&nbsp(£7.6m).Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.The films, actors and directors in the running for this year's awardsThe latest round of Oscar nominations are almost upon us and films fans are keeping their&nbspfingers crossed that they’ll be better than the ones announced for the Golden Globes and&nbspBaftas.This year’s ceremony, which – once again – won’t have a presenter, is set to take place in Los Angeles on 9 February. The nominations will be announced at 1.18pm GMT (very specific) and you’ll be able to follow along here.Among those expected to be nominated include Quentin Tarantino for Once Upon a Time in Hollywood&nbspand&nbspJoaquin Phoenix for his role in Joker. Elsewhere, Renée​ Zellweger&nbspis being tipped as this year’s Best Actress winner for Judy with both Little Women director Greta Gerwig and Us star Lupita Nyong’o also in the running for recognition.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesFollow along with all the nominations as they’re announced belowAll eyes are on the Academy after the Bafta nominations were criticised for a lack of ersityThese are all the big contenders and rank outsiders for trophiesThe odds are also hinting at who could win the biggest awards of the nightAlso, a nomination for Pugh would be great considering A) she was snubbed at the Golden Globes and B) because Little Women is extremely great.Next up, we have Best Supporting Actress.Now, we're gonna go ahead and assume that, just like with Roma last year, the Academy will recognise Parasite in some of the acting categories – they actually have quite&nbspa good rep for highlight standout performances from world cinema.&nbspThe Independent's predictions:&nbspTom Hanks – A Beautiful Day in the NeighbourhoodAl Pacino – The IrishmanJoe Pesci – The IrishmanSong Kang-ho – ParasiteBrad Pitt – Once Upon a Time in HollywoodOkay, let's e in and start with Best Supporting&nbspActor, which is otherwise known as: The Easiest Category to Predict.Yep, it's that time of year again – when the awards season hurtles towards its conclusion with the biggest&nbspceremony of them all that hopefully doesn't end with as big an anti-climax as Green Book winning Best Picture in 2019.The Academy Awards will take place on 9 FebruaryThe best in film, music, TV &amp radio straight to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Duke and Duchess of Sussex announced plans to step back as senior royals and spend time in North AmericaMeghan Markle is expected to join the Queen’s crunch talks about her and Prince Harry’s future roles by phone after returning to Canada.The monarch has called Harry, his brother Prince William, and their father Prince Charles to a crisis meeting at her private Norfolk estate of Sandringham where the “next steps” for the couple will be decided on Monday.It comes after Harry and Meghan released a bombshell statement outlining their plans to step back as senior royals, become financially independent, and split their time between the UK and North America.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe&nbspDuke and Duchess of Sussex&nbspmade the announcement on Wednesday without telling the Queen or other senior royals first.Meghan, who returned to Canada on Friday to be with the couple’s eight-month-old son Archie, is likely to join the talks via conference call, according to a royal source.&nbspCreated with Sketch.Everything that led to Prince Harry and Meghan Markle stepping down Show all 21Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Buckingham Palace said “a range of possibilities” would be discussed, but the Queen was determined to resolve the situation within “days, not weeks”.&nbspAmong the details that need to be worked out are who will pay for the couple’s currently taxpayer-funded security, what money-making activities they can undertake and what the tax consequences would be of moving to Canada or the United States.The crisis talks will take place amid speculation that Harry and Meghan could give a no-holds-barred interview which could be very damaging for the royal family, who are still reeling from Prince Andrew's links to paedophile Jeffrey Epstein.I have some idea of what might be aired in a full, no-holds-barred, sit-down interview and I don’t think it would be pretty, the couple's close friend Tom Bradby, the ITV news anchor, wrote in The Sunday Times.&nbspOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by email“They want to maintain the link of the family. It would be an absolute tragedy if it was done with a very bad feeling.”However William appeared on the front page of The Sunday Times, which reported that he was sad that he and Harry were “separate entities” because he wanted “everyone to play on the team”.Harry, who is sixth in line to the throne, married American actress Meghan Markle at Windsor Castle in 2018, and their son was born in May last year.Harry said in an October interview that he and William – destined one day to be king – were on “different paths”.The couple’s shock announcement last week came amid their growing unhappiness about their treatment by the media.&nbspRoyals who stepped back from their duties before Harry and MeghanHarry and Meghan being ‘driven out’ by Buckingham Palace, says friendTrump criticises Prince Harry and Meghan Markle Meghan Markle and Prince Harry post first Instagram since announcementMeghan and Prince Harry receive job offers following announcementHarry, who blames the press for the death of his mother, Princess Diana, in a Paris car crash in 1997, has long chafed at the intense scrutiny he receives.&nbspThe couple have sued several newspapers over allegedly intrusive coverage, and Harry has accused the media of targeting&nbspMeghan, who is mixed race, with abuse, some of it with “racial undertones.”Their decision to distance themselves from the royal family has drawn a mixed reaction from the British public.Many expressed sympathy for Meghan and Harry but said they should not receive taxpayer-funded security if they do not perform public duties.There has been widespread sympathy for the 93-year-old Queen, who attended church at Sandringham on Sunday, arriving by car dressed in a camel-coloured coat and hat.Members of the public gathering near St Mary Magdalene Church said they felt sorry for the Queen, with some saying that Harry and Meghan should not receive any more taxpayers’ money.Additional reporting by Press AssociationDuke and Duchess of title: conservatives racism tom hunt minority groups
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Equality campaigners accuse Ipswich MP Tom Hunt of 'ill-judged piece of dogwhistling'A Tory MP has been accused of fuelling racism after appearing to blame crime in his constituency on&nbspminority groups.Tom Hunt, the MP for Ipswich, claimed that a disproportionate number of offences in the town were committed by iniduals from certain communities.The claim&nbspdrew fire from a local racial equality group, which accused him of an ill-judged piece of dogwhistling.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesMr Hunt, who won the Ipswich seat from Labour at the general election, stood by his comments, although it remains&nbspunclear which communities he was referring to.The row erupted when the MP used a local newspaper column to raise concerns about theft and anti-social behaviour in Ipswich.Writing in the&nbspEast Anglian Daily Times, he&nbspsaid: It is impossible to start thinking about remedies to these issues without also being ready to confront the possibility that a disproportionate number of crimes are committed by iniduals from certain communities. This is something we should be open and honest about. Brushing it under the carpet will not get us closer to solving the issue.Brexit campaign had ‘racism at heart’, says Labour leader contenderUnfortunately, calling things how they are has not been a quality which we have come to expect from many in positions of responsibility on these matters. People who should know better are too quick to spout to politically correct mantras and too slow to call out problems in certain communities, hindering our ability to get to the bottom of the issue and leaving many residents and victims feeling like they don't have a voice.Continuing to link crime to immigrant communities, he&nbspcriticised people who say we should be eternally tolerant of bad behaviour which may be rife in other countries but is not traditionally in ours and said integration must include learning English, respecting women and obeying  our laws.Responding to the claims, a spokesperson&nbspfor the&nbspIpswich and Suffolk Council for Racial Equality (ISCRE) condemned the article as entirely evidence-free.They said: The recent article on the topic of crime in the EADT by the newly-elected MP for Ipswich is at best disappointing and at worst an ill-judged piece of dogwhistling.The latest news on Brexit, politics and beyond direct to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive updates on politics every morning by emailTom Hunt refers to 'certain communities' and the need for 'action....based on the facts as we see them', in relation to crime in our county town.Yet, his article is entirely evidence-free, which raises all sorts of uncomfortable questions about his purpose in writing it.They added: We believe that the people of Ipswich are way better than how Mr Hunt portrays them. A key ally of the current left-wing leadership of the party, the Salford &amp Eccles MP is viewed in some quarters as the natural successor to Mr Corbyn and describes herself as a “proud socialist”. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Could views formed over a lifetime of opposing American intervention translate into effective strategy?When Bolivia's leftist president was pressured to resign by his country's military after an audit found signs of a tainted election two months ago, many American leaders showed little interest in condemning the ousting. Some said it was a potentially positive step for democracy – a sign, as Donald Trump put it, that the will of the people will always prevail.&nbspA sharply different response came from senator Bernie Sanders, who immediately condemned what appears to be a coup. The ousted leader, Evo Morales, who had challenged term limits to remain in power, later thanked the senator from Vermont and Democratic&nbsppresidential candidate, referring to him affectionately as brother.Most of Mr Sanders' rivals paid little attention to the incident in a faraway place. But for Mr Sanders, the episode offered a glimpse into an unorthodox foreign policy worldview – anchored by a passionate opposition to US&nbspmilitary interventions – that has been overshadowed by his famously liberal domestic policy agenda.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesWith the Iran crisis thrusting foreign affairs to the forefront of the campaign, just as Mr Sanders rises in early state polls, Democrats who previously waved off the senator's views as fringe ideas now must contemplate the possibility of a democratic socialist becoming commander in chief of the United States. Mr Trump has already upended the world order with an America First approach that tests Western alliances, and Mr Sanders would deliver another jolt – echoing some of Mr Trump's criticisms of military actions and free trade but realigning the country's priorities even more thoroughly.Beyond his objection to Mr Morales' removal, Mr Sanders has pointedly declined to label Venezuelan president Nicolas Maduro a dictator. He called Israeli prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu a racist, and has campaigned with representatives&nbspRashida Tlaib&nbspand Ilhan Omar&nbspvocal supporters of a controversial Israel boycott movement. You've had a consensus in this country on certain principles. Joe Biden represents that consensus. And to a degree, Obama as well.Even some Democrats note that Mr Sanders has put much more emphasis on domestic policies than global ones. It hasn't been his strong suit, senator&nbspRichard Durbin said of Mr Sanders' foreign policy.&nbspMr Sanders and his supporters say he's been right on foreign policy far more than the supposed experts, and that the establishment is responsible for a series of misguided military adventures. Besides, they say, Mr Sanders' positions are often more nuanced than he's given credit for – he has criticised Mr Morales and Mr Maduro, for example, even while questioning the wisdom of removing them.Democrats and Republicans are equally incompetent over SoleimaniWhat were the two major foreign policy blunders in our lifetimes? Help me out here. What were they? Vietnam was one, and Iraq was the other, Mr Sanders said Saturday at a town hall in Newton, Iowa. I marched against the war in Vietnam. I was a kid. As a United States congressman in 2002, 2003, I helped lead the effort to prevent us from invading Iraq.Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailMr Sanders' campaign declined to make him available for an interview. In a statement, Mr Sanders' national policy director Josh Orton said: Washington's foreign policy establishment has been consistently wrong, and that a Sanders administration would begin to repair the damage done by Trump.Mr Sanders, 78, was strongly influenced by the Reagan-era US&nbspinterventions in Latin America, which appalled many liberals. Those years also influenced his broader approach to the region, which stands apart from many Democrats. Mr Sanders was at odds with many in the party last year, for example, when he refused to call Mr Maduro a dictator, even as he made critical comments about the authoritarian socialist leader.His comments about Mr&nbspMorales, whose success lifting Bolivians into the middle class made him an iconic figure among socialists, also stood out. At a Univision forum, Mr Sanders praised Mr Morales for addressing poverty and empowering indigenous people. He added that it was fair to question whether he should have stayed in power so long – almost 14 years – but it was a far less critical approach than other Democrats took towards a man whom many viewed as increasingly authoritarian.Mr Sanders has been accused by members of both parties of not being tough enough on repressive socialist regimes. He's not going to pretend we face remotely equivalent threats from left-wing authoritarianism than from right-wing authoritarianism, said a senior Sanders aide, speaking on the condition of anonymity to be candid.When he ran for president four years ago, Mr Sanders often appeared unprepared for a rigorous foreign policy debate. Facing opponent Hillary Clinton, a former secretary of state, he often sidestepped questions about specific global challenges.&nbspFollowing his loss, Mr Sanders sought to shore up his foreign policy credentials. After the 2016 election, he hired Matt Duss, who has helped the candidate with his foreign policy chops. Now his top foreign policy hand – and seen inside Mr Sanders' world as a potential future national security adviser –Mr&nbspDuss rose from blogging about policy to helming the Foundation for Middle East Peace.&nbspIn the years after his loss to Ms Clinton, Mr Sanders delivered some lengthy speeches on foreign policy, including one at Westminster College in Missouri, where Winston Churchill gave his famous Iron Curtain address.&nbspThat 2017 Sanders speech encapsulated much of his thinking on world affairs, people close to him said. In it, he tethered his foreign policy vision to his populist domestic agenda, declaring, We cannot convincingly promote democracy abroad if we do not live it vigorously here at home.Mr Sanders argued that the events of the past two decades have discredited the notion that the US&nbspshould use its military might to shape the world to its liking. He decried US&nbspinterference in Iran and Chile in the 20th century. He underlined the need for alliances to confront adversaries such as North Korea. On a smaller scale, he touted the value of partnering with a sister city in Russia when he was mayor of Burlington, Vermont.&nbspMany Democrats remain unimpressed. On the campaign trail, Mr Sanders has increasingly clashed with Mr Biden, who touts his extensive foreign policy experience in the Senate and Obama administration.David Lammy, the&nbspBritish MP, who has gotten to know Mr Sanders in recent years, noted that Sanders' views would fit more comfortably in a typical European centre-left party. Whether he were in Germany or France or the UK, of course, Bernie, his politics would be very familiar and probably quite mainstream, Mr&nbspLammy said.He added, Clearly, in the US&nbspcontext, it has been a slightly different experience.While Mr Sanders' unorthodox views make some Democrats nervous, the most pointed hostility comes from Republicans. Asked what he thinks of Mr Sanders' foreign policy platform, senator&nbspThom Tillis said, A disaster.&nbspStanding next to him in an elevator in the Capitol Building was senator&nbspRick Scott&nbspwho chuckled and interjected, Does he have a foreign policy?&nbspYet this is a time of foreign policy upheaval in both parties. Mr Trump himself has upended decades of Republican thinking, praising figures such as North Korean leader Kim Jong Un while questioning the role of Nato. A populist non-interventionism is surging in both parties, championed by figures such as representative&nbspTulsi Gabbard and senator Rand Paul.That has given Mr&nbspSanders a sometimes surprising array of foreign policy partners on Capitol Hill. He teamed up with senator Mike Lee, a conservative Republican from Utah, on a measure to end US support for the Saudi-led military campaign in Yemen. Their legislation passed the Senate and forced Mr Trump to issue his second veto.&nbspSanders introduces law to stop Trump from starting war with IranOn Saturday, Mr Lee signed onto Mr Sanders' bill to prevent Mr Trump from deploying funds for military action against Iran without congressional approval.Other alliances have been more controversial. Representatives Ilhan Omar and Rashida&nbspTlaib, who have endorsed Mr Sanders for president, strongly support the Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions (BDS) movement to pressure Israel over its policies towards Palestinians.&nbspMany Democrats and Republicans, including some who have criticised Israeli policies, object to the BDS movement as going too far. To me, BDS has no place, said senator Ben Cardin, formerly the top Democrat on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.&nbspMr Sanders himself does not support the BDS movement. But he has been a vocal critic of Mr Netanyahu, and he has said he is willing to make foreign aid to Israel contingent on fostering more peaceful relations with Palestinians, a condition many Democrats and Republicans are unwilling to impose.&nbspWhen it comes to international trade, Mr Sanders opposes an emerging US&nbspdeal with Mexico and Canada, arguing that it does not go far enough in protecting American jobs. The deal has the support of the union AFL-CIO and&nbspElizabeth Warren among others on the left.To some moderate Democrats, including senator&nbspJon Tester of Montana, Mr Sanders' message at times can resemble the current president's promises to avoid needless wars. Kind of like Trump? Mr Tester mused in a brief interview at the Capitol. Mr Sanders' identification as a democratic socialist is something he has to overcome in his pitch to be commander in chief, Mr Tester added.Trade politics also ided Mr Sanders and&nbspBarack Obama. He may have more differences with Obama on foreign policy than Trump, is the great irony, said John Cavanagh, who has known Mr Sanders since 1991 and directs the Institute for Policy Studies, a liberal think tank. Both he and Trump can sit down with workers in the Midwest. It's just that one does it in a racist and xenophobic way.But Mr Sanders has his stark differences with Mr Trump as well. The senator from Vermont was a lonely voice opposing the most recent defence spending bill. And Mr Sanders favours international diplomacy to tackle big issues such as the Paris climate accord.Until recently, Mr Sanders' proposals have been overshadowed by his sweeping domestic agenda. But the US&nbspkilling of Iranian military commander Qassem Soleimani prompted Mr Sanders to amplify the linchpin of his foreign agenda: his long-standing opposition to US&nbspintervention abroad.&nbspNews of the airstrike came late 2 January, after Mr Sanders had spent the day campaigning in Iowa. Inside a restaurant at the Doubletree Hotel in Cedar Rapids, Mr Sanders huddled with aides including campaign manager Faiz Shakir and his deputy, Ari Rabin-Havt, according to a person with knowledge of the situation. Mr&nbspDuss, the foreign policy adviser, joined by phone. Together, they crafted a statement calling the killing an assassination and drew a connection to the instability caused by the Iraq War.&nbspIt gives me no pleasure to tell you at this moment we face a similar crossroads fraught with danger, he said the next day during a town hall meeting at the National Motorcycle Museum in Anamosa, Iowa, delivering a speech he wrote and then revised on the drive from the hotel, according to the aide with knowledge of the situation.For some at the town hall, his aversion to military conflict resonated. We've been through this in the past, said Thomas Wiand, 51. We went through unnecessary wars continually.Against all odds, it looks like Bernie Sanders might be the nomineeOthers were more cautious. Sometimes you have to go and do what needs to be done to correct the situation, said Craig Bruxvoort, 62, a grain farmer who applauded Mr Trump for ordering general Soleimani's killing.&nbspThose who have worked with Mr&nbspSanders on foreign policy describe him as methodical and inquisitive. Suzanne DiMaggio, a senior fellow at the Carnegie Endowment who is advising Mr Sanders on Iran, recalled him asking specific questions about the consequences of general Soleimani's killing.&nbspA lot of the questions focused on the internal political dynamics in Iran: What are the likely scenarios that will now emerge? How will it affect those who are moderates in Iran? Ms DiMaggio said.&nbspBen Rhodes, who served as deputy national security adviser under Mr Obama, remembered briefing Mr Sanders on the Iran nuclear deal for about an hour,&nbspas the senator fired questions his way.A more vivid memory for Mr Rhodes was how Mr Sanders was affected by talking to veterans and family members of soldiers killed in combat.&nbspI remember him telling me once, he said, 'Obama doesn't get enough credit for how many troops Obama took out from Afghanistan,' said Mr Rhodes, who has offered informal advice to Mr Sanders and other candidates. title: samira ahmed wins bbc equal pay
story: The Newswatch host was told she should have got the same as Jeremy Vine, who earned £, an episode for Points Of View.Samira, , insisted their roles were comparable — but the BBC argued it was not similar work.Yesterday, an employment tribunal ruled in favour of Samira, who earned just £ an episode, saying: “The dference in pay in this case is striking.”It said Jeremy, , just had to read from a script, adding: “If it told him to roll his eyes he did. It did not require any particular skill or experience to doBut the tribunal did not say whether Samira should get the £, she said she was owed.The ruling, following a hearing in November in London, will have major implications for BBC pay.Ms Ahmed said: “I’m now looking forward to reporting on stories and not being one.”Carrie Gracie, who quit as BBC China editor two years ago over pay, told her: “I could not be more proud of you.I hope your victory gives courage to women to stand up for the value of their work.”But the BBC insisted: “We have always believed that the pay of Samira and Jeremy Vine was not determined by their gender.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sun says harry meghan bankrolled
story: Their plan for global domination as Instagram’s “progressive” royal power couple looks fatally flawed.First it relies on them still being bankrolled by an increasingly enraged public — as they magnanimously “work to become financially independent” despite already being worth sums most of us cannot imagine.Second, because when they finally deem their wealth vast enough to cut that umbilical cord, their livelihood will still centre around their image as senior royals . . . a role they have quit.The idea of them busily enriching themselves by flogging their part-time royalty to advertisers will disgust taxpayers — both on principle and because this ­entitled pair will never refund a penny back into Treasury coffers.The UK public will justiably demand they be cut off at the ankles, stripped of the titles on which they trade.What then for plain Meghan and Harry Wales, the narcissist formerly known as Prince Who will listen then to their vapid sermons  They might fancy themselves as the new Clintons or Obamas — but they have not earned their  or status.They were born into it, or married into it, but gave it up when it all looked too dull, too hard and not enough fun.Diehard fans will stick by them. They will doubtless make big money. But the firestorm of criticism they have ignited here will become an inferno.It is a disastrous mess and may get worse. The couple’s assumption about the public continuing to fund round-the-clock security in Canada looks ­premature — and must be reviewed.Harry is worth £million, Meghan another £million. How much richer must they be before they pay that bill WHY is the Government still so coy about celebrating the moment of Brexit Leaving the EU at pm on January  will be a huge milestone in our modern history, the end of our -year membership and the starting gun for negotiating a lucrative new era of trade.The Sun wants Big Ben to bong. We want bunting, fireworks and, yes, commemorative Royal Mail stamps.We understand the feelings of Remainers. But there were plenty of them among the million who voted last month to “get Brexit done”.The big day is less than three weeks away following its final passage through the Commons on Thursday.How typical of Labour, given one last chance to vote for the deal securing our exit, to remain childishly opposed to it.Defeated in the referendum, crushed at the election. title: boris should not bend opinion
story: Previously, in weeks where Brexit legislation was before the Commons, discussion was dominated by whether or not the Government had the numbers to win the vote and how it should respondit did not.This time there was barely a mention of Brexit despite the votes on it this week. .Pretty much all Boris Johnson had to say on the matter was to urge ministers to, “banish Brexit”, from their lexicons after January , when the UK leaves the EU.Boris wants ministers to stop talking about Brexit once the UK has left as he doesn’t want the trade negotiations with the EU to dominate British politics in the way that leaving has since the referendum. He wants to show voters that the country has moved on and the Government is once more focusing on the domestic issues voters care about.But however much he tries, it will be hard to make these talks boring. They are important and there is already DRAMA BREWING.Boris saw the new Commission President Ursula von der Leyen in Downing Street this week. The pair got on well in their hour-long meeting. They both want these talks to be less acrimonious than the orce negotiations both want a more cordial tone.The pair reminisced about the school they had both attended in Brussels. Unlike Eton, it didn’t have playing fields, and until Johnson arrived the only game in the playground was marbles. He introduced some more rough and tumble.No were pleased that von der Leyen, rather than the more confrontational Michel Barnier, took the lead. As one No source points out, the EU loathed the lack of clarity and authority under Theresa May: She wasn’t clear what she wanted and it wasn’t certain that she could deliver what she wanted.With Boris and his new majority it is very dferent. He was able to point von der Leyen to the Tory manesto’s commitments on the future trade deal and say this was his mandate and that he was determined to deliver it.Yet despite the pair’s attempt to maintain a friendly tone, there are already tensions. Boris is irritated that the EU keeps saying it is nigh-on impossible to negotiate a full trade deal by December , despite having signed up to a political declaration that commits it to trying to do just that.The DANGER is that the EU thinks that under time pressure Boris will bend, that he will either extend the transition period — something he has repeatedly promised not to do — or drop his commitment to breaking away from EU rules and regulations.Boris is determined not to do either of these things. He doesn’t want to extend and believes in the value of the UK having the right to do things dferently.Both sides have frequently misunderstood each other in this process. Both sides must now realise that the other means what it says. Unless they do, there is going to be an almighty bust-up and no trade deal at the end of all this.THERE will be a National Security Council meeting later this month to decide whether or not to allow the Chinese company Huawei to be involved in the construction of the UK’s G network.This is an issue of fierce debate in Whitehall. Under Theresa May, it led to the then Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson’s sacking from government.Hawkish figures inside government fear No is leaning towards allowing Huawei’s involvement. One complains that Downing Street’s timetable for the technology’s roll-out is, “not realistic”, but that this time pressure means it will need Huawei involved. However, I understand that the Americans are pushing very hard for the UK to bar Huawei.One senior US government national security figure has been in London this week to lobby directly on this point.Before he makes a decision on Huawei, Boris Johnson should consider the damage it could do to Britain’s most important security relationship – the Five Eyes intelligence-sharing agreement with Australia, Canada, the US and New Zealand.Eventhe UK thinks it can manage Huawei’s involvement,our allies do not then we shouldn’t proceed. It is simply not worth the risk of undermining such a vital alliance.Don’t expect his approach to change. His holidays will be far more glam than Cameron and May’s were.THE most common reason British governments fail is that the Prime Minister and the Chancellor fall out.If No and the Treasury – the most powerful department in government – aren’t on the same page, nothing gets done.Boris Johnson and Sajid Javid are determined to avoid this fate. In the run-up to the Budget on March , there will be a huge effort to make sure that the Treasury and No work together.One Johnson ally tells me the two men will have a Budget-focused meeting at the start of each week to make sure they are in agreement on the key issues.Then their teams will meet again mid-week to assess progress. Javid, whose job is safe in the coming reshuffle, is determined to show that the Treasury is capable of delivering on Boris Johnson’s agenda of levelling up across the country.Those close to him are confident that they can put meat on the bones of No’s plan.AT Cabinet this week it was impressed on ministers that one of the most important events this year is COP, the climate change conference the UK is hosting in Glasgow in November.The UK Government wants to use the event to show how Britain can lead on clean growth post-Brexit.I understand there will be a steady drum beat of announcements on this front throughout the year: The Tories want to show they are helping create new green-collar jobs.They also hope that by holding the event in Scotland, they can emphasise the benefits of the Union.THE Labour leadership contest has yet to catch fire.The Tories are not particularly concerned about any of the candidates.Though there is some hesitation about how they would handle PMQs with Jess Phillips, who likes to make very personal attacks on Boris Johnson.But the most interesting candidate in the race is Lisa Nandy.She seems to have the clearest understanding of why Labour lost.Her bid is starting to have faint echoes of David Cameron’s successful tilt at the Tory leadership in .GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: queen landmark meeting heated atmosphere
story: To my knowledge, something like this has never happened before in terms of what it is all about and that it is happening so quickly.This is the ultimate summit between the head of state, the two heirs to the head of state and the sixth in line to the throne.With Charles and Diana’s orce, the Queen wrote to them inidually saying they had to start talking and sort orce proceedings. She didn’t meet them.Even the abdication of Edward VIII over Mrs Simpson, together below, was at Government and Church level.To have documents prepared in advance does not surprise me. The Queen has said she wants this sorted out and without delay.Many have called this an abdication and in one sense it is. Harry and Meghan expect to still have a handle on royal duty but also to lead a private le.What they mean by living financially independent, I don’t know. They aren’t financially independent now — they get £.- million from the Prince Of Wales and about five per cent from the Sovereign Grant.Harry is reasonably wealthy but not necessarily in cash flow. The sums he inherited from his mother and great grandmother have been invested.Meghan has some means but to live the sort of lestyle they are used to takes a lot of money.It is conceivable Charles could cut the money he gives to Harry —he gives him any at all. Being a dad, he probably will.But there are tax implications — particularlythere are handouts.Security has also to be considered. Harry is a prince of the United Kingdom, his grandmother head of state and father heir.The atmosphere at the meeting will be, up to a point, heated. But people won’t lose their tempers.The Queen is pragmatic. She understands problems people have but Harry will be fully aware of her displeasure. To go off half-cocked as he and Meghan did is unacceptable.The question is how dare they do that. She signed up for this. So what’s changed their minds I’d love to be a fly on the wall of the events in that meeting . . . provided no one has a fly swat!Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: see back of harry and meghan
story: What a waste of the mountain of goodwill there was towards that happy, glamorous couple who wed on a sunshine-soaked day in Windsor in . And what a waste of their chance to play a key role in helping our Royal Family prosper after the Queen is gone.And what a waste of Harry and Meghan’s unique chance to be a living, inspirational representation of the multiracial country in which we now live. How quickly the shine has come off the golden couple.Less than two years after that wedding day, Harry and Meghan are scurrying off to an ill-defined “progressive” new le in Canada.Butthey have been unhappy with their royal roles, they have brought it on themselves. This much-loved couple have always been too thin-skinned for their own good.They have always been hysterically touchy when justied criticism came their way, such as when they lectured about climate change while reclining on private jets.The criticism was nothing personal. Hollywood stars get called out for climate hypocrisy. Do Harry and Meghan really imagine we will just tug our forelocks as they fly around the world in private jets while talking like Greta Thunberg in a tiara Harry and Meghan are never satisfied with anything less than unconditional deference. They apparently loathe royal le, yet demand to be treated like royalty.They have demonstrated an epic sense of entitlement, such as asking the taxpayer to pick up the £.million builder’s bill for doing up their home, Frogmore Cottage.Their great self-pitying delusion is that the wicked British media has it in for them. But it is not the media that caused Meghan so much excruciating embarrassment.It is largely her own dysal family and their indiscreetly flapping cakeholes, especially her dear old discarded dad Thomas Markle and her loony half-sister Samantha. Harry and Meghan’s self-pity is astounding.“Never complain, never explain,” has been the motto of the modern Royal Family. It has worked rather well.But place Harry and Meghan in front of a sympathetic camera crew, such as when ITV’s Tom Bradby trailed them on their tour of South Africa, and they can’t stop whining. Even when surrounded by victims of rape and landmines, they managed to feel sorry for themselves.“Not many people askedI’m OK,” Meghan complained in the Third World. There has not been a royal couple with such a staggering lack of self-awareness since Marie Antoinette and King Louis XVI of France. And look what happened to them.Harry and Meghan owe their mega-celebrity totally to their connection with the Royal Family. Their superstardom has nothing to do with Meghan’s acting career. Their lives of unimaginable luxury are funded in large part by the British taxpayer.The average couple spends just under £, on their wedding. Harry and Meghan were said to have blown £MILLION. Yet they do not appear to have a grateful bone between them. They seem incapable of counting their multiple blessings.Even now, after handing in their royal resignation, they give every indication that they want all the privileges of royal le with none of the obligations. They want to have their Eton mess and eat it.Harry and Meghan’s security alone currently costs around £, a year, paid for by the politan Police — which means paid for by the British taxpayer. Get the Mounties to start paying for it.And can we finally nail the great lie that Meghan has been persecuted in the UK because of her mixed race  When she first appeared, Meghan was a hurricane of fresh air. The British looked at her and it was love at first sight.This weary, ided, Brexit-battered nation was delighted to have an injection of Hollywood glamour. And millions of Brits now live in mixed-race families. There was real delight to see the Royal Family catching up with the rest of us.Among those crowds at Windsor on their wedding day I saw families of every race and creed under the sun who were ecstatic to see the Royal Family becoming less white, more inclusive, more representative.Harry and Meghan have drawn criticism because of their total lack of self-awareness. Both of them are independently rich. Harry is worth around £million after inheritances from his mother and the Queen Mum.Prince Charles gives him £million every year. Meghan made around £million from her role in long-runningTV legal drama Suits.Yet this fabulously wealthy couple have been happy to let others — the British taxpayer, Prince Charles, the Queen — pay their way in their gilded world.Six weeks, which is theof time that Harry and Meghan have just spent in Canada, is a very long time to be away from home.Unless, of course, “home” doesn’t feel like home because you feel criticised for everything you do and wear, your family – on both sides – are a nightmare and you are constantly judgedby people who have never met you and never will.I should imagine that in this case, Canada seems like a very good place to call home. So, who can blame Meghan and Harry for deciding to leave the UK behind to get away from it all, and maybe staying away from here in the long-term I have a lot of respect for the couple for ploughing their own furrow and walking their own path.Honestly, I couldn’t be happier for Harry, who has experienced so much sadness, that he has met a woman brave enough to suggest doing things a bit dferently.Although they are currently making bold statements about giving up the taxpayer-funded Sovereign Grant, they show no sign of being willing to pay for their own security, or their own flunkies, or offer the taxpayer a rebate on those reported £million nuptials.There has never been even the slightest hint of gratitude. There has never been any indication that they — this rich, pampered couple with a beautul baby boy who will never want for anything — realise how lucky they are.So Harry and Meghan are not the only ones with mixed emotions today. There is real resentment that Harry and Meghan have caused distress to our Queen and it will not be easily forgotten or forgiven.The Queen has a -year-old husband who has recently been in hospital. She has a son mired in a squalid sex scandal. And she is  years old. Who the hell do Harry and Meghan think they are This feels like an abdication with a taxpayer-funded safety net. The couple plan to “step back as senior members of the Royal Family” but show no inclination to give up the privileges and pay days that come with the job.They say they want to “work to become financially independent”. But between them they are currently worth around £million. Why not pay their own way NOW Are they really suggesting that they turn their backs on this nation while asking it to foot their bills  It looks like it. The British taxpayer will continue to stump up for their phenomenal security bills. Harry’s daddy will cough up for much .So you can’t help wondering how intelligent they really are, this TV soap actress and a man who left Eton with two A-levels— a school where my dog could get four A-levels.Do Harry and Meghan really think they have had a raw deal  Are they that stupid  There is no republican movement in this country.The Queen has reigned far too well for far too long —  years on the throne next month — for anti-monarchy sentiment to develop.The Queen has spent her entire le placing public duty above private happiness.She has been the stable, stoic centre of this nation for so long that she has single-handedly made losing our monarchy unthinkable.Yet when a spokesman for anti-monarchy pressure group Republic demanded Harry and Meghan make a clean break, I found myself nodding in agreement with every withering word.“Theyhave said that they will dip in and out of royal duties as it suits them but won’t stop taking money until they find other sources of income,” said Republic’s Graham Smith.“To suggest they’re not already financially independent is incredibly crass and belies a sense of entitlement and lack of self-awareness common among royals.”This republican is right. If Harry and Meghan want a new le hanging out with the Clooneys and striking deals with Apple, they should fund it themselves.As they say in North America, do it on your own dime. Give up the HRH titles. Stop leeching off your royal status.They will be a footnote in the story of our Royal Family, Meghan the Wallis Simpson of the st Century, Harry another Duke of Windsor who believed exile with his American orcee would make him happy.The Royal Family is not all about them.The Queen will be an impossible act to follow. But the photograph of Queen Elizabeth smiling proudly with the next three generations of future kings — Princes Charles, William and George — suggests our Royal Family will last for at least  years after Netflix has cancelled The Crown, evenone day Meghan gets to play herself.The succession is assured. Decent men will wear the crown. And Kate is great. But let history record that no royal couple was ever as adored as Harry and Meghan.It is astonishing — and unbelievably sad, perhaps even tragic — that millions of us will be happy to see the back of them.Astrological patterns repeat in families through generations, just as it is doing with Meghan and Harry.Edward VIII, who wed American orcee Wallis Simpson, put love before duty, and planted a karmic seed that is at the root of what is unfolding now. It can be likened to a virus that has been lurking in the Royal household and is now being re-activated by Harry and Meghan.So what comes next  Uranus, the planet of shock-waves, moves to confront the Sun in Aquarius on January  and forms a clash with the New Moon on the th.There is likely to be a stinging backlash as all the remaining senior family members have their roles shaken up.Meghan will create a power couple that flourishes by spring with a number of initiatives. By December , another baby announcement is likely.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: blind eye iran no longer option
story: No president could ignore the killing of US contractors, the invasion of its embassy in Baghdad, the threat to the lives of American service personnel.If that threat was imminent, he was right to act. We would have done the same to protect British servicemen and women. In fact, as Britain’s Defence Secretary I did exactly that, with the full support of Prime Minister David Cameron.Let’s not forget that every country has the right to self-defence.Of course, nobody wants this crisis to escalate. Indeed Iran’s retaliation has been noticeably limited so far.But the chorus for “de-escalation” carries risks too. Iran has been attacking Western shipping, including capturing a British tanker. Iran has fired missiles at Saudi oil refineries.Iran continues to wage proxy wars in Lebanon, Syria and Yemen. Through its militias, Iran continues to destabilise neighbouring Iraq.At some point, somebody had to draw the line. Qasem Soleimani was no hero or statesman. He directed terrorist attacks across the Middle East.Thousands of Syrians, Iraqis and Yemenis died as a result. Iranian dissidents, too, were brutally suppressed.The roadside bomb-making he sponsored killed many of our brave servicemen in Iraq. As Prime Minister Boris Johnson reminded us, he had the blood of our soldiers on his hands.Has Trump’s strike weakened the case for Western intervention  It is worth remembering our troops and those of the US are in Iraq at Iraq’s invitation.Since , we have helped lead an international coalition of more than  countries to support its fragile democracy and liberate that country from the terrorist death-cult of Daesh Isis.And thanks to precision strikes by the RAF and the training by the British Army of thousands of Iraqi troops, Daesh has lost the pernicious grip it once had.Defeating Daesh isn’t just a matter of helping a friend in need or of standing up for human rights. Mercully, we have stopped Yazidi women from being raped, prisoners being burnt alive, gay people being thrown off buildings and Western hostages sadistically executed.But tackling Daesh terrorism is also vital to protect our own way of le here in Western Europe.Islamist fundamentalism needs to be defeated, whether in Mosul, Raqqa, a Paris suburb or on London Bridge.So yes, let’s continue to work with our allies to persuade Iran’s revolutionaries to take a dferent path.Saudi Arabia, the other Gulf countries and even Russia all have roles to play in getting Iran back to the negotiating table.After the appalling shooting down of the Ukrainian airliner, let’s try to show the Iranian people their government needs to be more truthful and more open, that there is a better future beyond the mullahs and the republican guards.But diplomacy alone will not be enough. We have to protect our national interests too. Trump’s strike is a stark reminder that in the end, we must all stand up when those interests are threatened so directly.First, we must persuade other European navies to work with the US and our own Royal Navy in patrolling and protecting convoys through the Strait of Hormuz.This is a vital choke point for Europe’s trade and energy. The gas and oil we need this winter pass through it.It is ludicrous that some Nato allies won’t work with American ships for fear of upsetting the mullahs in Tehran.This has to be a US-led international operation.Second, we need a better nuclear agreement with Iran. It was right to try to halt their nuclear programme. But the previous deal wasn’t comprehensive — it didn’t even cover missiles — and it completely failed to constrain Iranian misbehaviour in the region. If anything, Iran used the access to new finance that deal released to step up its proxy wars in Yemen and where.A new deal should ensure full oversight of all Iran’s nuclear activities by the International Atomic Energy Agency, and only allow Iran back into the international markets when its civil nuclear programme is in complete compliance.Third, we have to step up our campaign against terrorism.Outside the EU after Brexit, we will still need to share intelligence and work together with our European partners to identy new attacks. But our closest ally in the battle to protect our values will always be the US. We may not always agree with Trump’s tactics but we shouldn’t ignore that he has finally cut through the illusion — Iran’s current regime is not our friend.Iran will certainly have learned a lesson from President Trump’s decisive action. But I hope we will do so too.Turning a blind eye to those who foster international terrorism is no longer an option for any of us.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: what you do after mistakes important
story: But in all honesty, what really matters is not so much what happened but how we respond.Take the young woman who was in court this week after drunkenly propositioning male passengers on a flight from Abu Dhabi to Manchester. She askedthey wanted to join her in the “mile-high club”, then attacked cabin crew who refused her more alcohol.Demi Burton tried to headbutt and kick six crew members and passengers who tried to restrain her before she was arrested when the plane landed.In court, the -year-old claimed she had been drinking because she has a fear of flying and said this behaviour is out of character, which may be true.Her defence lawyer Martin Callery said: “She is thoroughly ashamed of herself . . .  and utterly embarrassed at the way she behaved.”But that is certainly not the impression she conveyed outside court, where she gleefully flicked obscene hand gestures at photographers.No doubt she stopped smiling when she heard she had been sentenced to six months in prison. Personally, I’m not sure how effective prison is. But the problem with reckless behaviour is that you have to face the consequences.And I really hope for Demi, this is the moment she gets her le back on track. We all make mistakes. It’s what we do afterwards that defines us.It would be easy to assume that Demi is a hopeless case. But she is young enough to turn her le around, to work hard, do better and see this rock-bottom moment as a catalyst for change.And then something good will come from what is a very low moment in her le. We don’t have to look far for examples of people who have overcome lapses or mistakes before going on to succeed.Take Robert Downey Jr, who went from drug addict to one of Hollywood’s highest-paid actors. Or Elton John and Robbie Williams, both of whom have overcome major drug issues before enjoying renewed stardom, fatherhood and, more importantly, a good le.While it is not the same as a drunken mistake, anyone who has made it in business will have a good few failures under their belt — whether it is a dodgy commercial decision, plain bad luck or a company that has gone bust.It is not what happens to us in le but what we do next that counts. So I am guessing that, from her cell, Demi might be reflecting on what she might do dferently when she gets out. Andshe isn’t, she should be.Because it is the getting back on the horse that counts, evenit means resisting the urge to go back to bed to hide. No one is perfect. No one gets through le without messing up or things going wrong.Before success, you will get temporary defeat or total failure. The key to getting through it is resilience. And one of the best gts you can give a child is to encourage them not to give up.By the way, I speak here from experience. Like any businesswoman, I’ve made some mistakes and had my fair share of knocks.There are some that I have managed to turn to my advantage and others that I have had to chalk up to experience.The key thing is that I have learned from what went wrong, then moved on. That experience has allowed me to create a mini-manesto on how to fail how to respond to setbacks and failure, which I’ll share here now:Give yourself time to recover and reflect. Force yourself to take small steps to get back on the horse. Do not accept failure. See it as a step on the journey towards success.Remember that challenging and dficult moments are what help you grow bigger or better. Without them, you would stay the same.The only people who haven’t experienced setbacks are people who are too scared to try. So “failure” is often a sign of bravery. Hold your head up high at all times.Try your best and be proud to do so, eventhings don’t always work out the way you want them to. Remind yourself: “Where there is a will, there’s a way.” And as they say, the best thing about the future is it comes one day at a time.ANOTHER new year, another month of looking at photos of scantily clad people on beaches in sunnier climes and asking myselfI am the only person who is not on the beach.This is the time of year for massive bikini-body and holiday FOMO.But let us all take heart that it is also, oh joy, the time of year for elasticated waists hidden under chunky knitwear.Personally, I am more than happy to swap the beach for nothing to shave and no stomach to suck in. Bliss.I’M sure parents everywhere were shocked to read the story of the son who bullied his mother and stepfather so viciously he has been jailed for three years for his controlling and coercive behaviour.When Nicholas Hazell, , of County Durham, went back to live with Judith Ridley, , and her reverend husband Stephen, , after losing his job, he made their lives hell.Hazell, above, created a “horrendous atmosphere” at the family home and flew into a petulant ragehe didn’t get his own way, Durham Crown Court heard.Among his worst outbursts were when Hazell threw his mother into a chair and spat at her while holding a screwdriver to his stepfather’s throat. He also told them: “I am a master of bullying.”It sounds horric.I feel so sorry for his mum, who must be devastated that her little boy turned into a cruel bully as an adult.I dont do needles when it comes to my face.  Lasers, facials, peels . . .  sure. But needles are another story entirely.If you are willing to take the chance of injecting poison into your face, at the very least you want a predictable result. And in my experience, you don’t get it.Who wants eyebrows at the top of their head, lips that come into the room before you do, or a forehead that doesn’t move  Not me, that’s for sure. However . . .This week I read that not only is the gorgeous Abbey Clancy having micro-Botox injections, hyaluronic acid fillers and vitamins, she is doing it with TWENTY needles at once.Abbey, , is having something called an aquagold facial, so called because each needle is covered in -carat gold. The marketing blurb claims this treatment will reduce pores, blur out fine lines and leave your skin with a vibrant glow.Some might say this is a slippery slope to the stronger stuff but Abbey looks amazing.  So it has to be worth a try, don’t you think I HAD to laugh at the photos of the BBC newsreader whose dress, which had burst open minutes before going on air, was cobbled together from behind by quick-thinking colleagues.  Liz Beacon’s outfit was patched up with gaffer tape and bulldog clips.I used to believe what I saw on TV. But since filming The Apprentice, I know all too well that all is not necessarily what it seems.Two examples spring to mind. First, the countless times I have been filmed in the boardroom with a smart jacket on top and leggings or even pyjama bottoms and slippers under the boardroom table.Second, and worse, the time I somehow forgot to bring a bra on a day I was wearing a white blouse.Luckily, a kind crew member who is roughly the same size as me lent me hers.  And the show, as it always seems to do, went on.I WAS appalled to read about the private Islamic secondary school that has been “unlawfully segregating” boys and girls for all activities except weekly assemblies, according to a stinging Ofsted report.One of the teachers theretold pupils “university is not for females”, according to the report. Which begs the question of where, then, is the best place for females  The kitchen Inspectors who visited Birmingham’s Redstone Educational Academy in November last year also found male students were given privileges and treated more favourably than their female counterparts when it came to sports, school trips and work experience.That was something disputed by the headteacher.That’s not good enough. There can be no place for a school like this and it should be closed down.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: labour contender clive lewis sparks outcry after claiming brexit vote had racism at its core
story: The Norwich South MP said non-white Britons woke up with a “sense of dread” the day after the referendum, which will see Britain finally leave on January .Having previously suggested racism was a reason some Labour MPs were not backing him, the arch-Remainer now also claimed it was integral to Brexit.He said: “I think part of the Brexit campaign, and part of the undertone of Brexit, from some politicians, Nigel Farage and others, had racism at its core and its heart.“They used it as a mechanism to ide our communities, to ide our country.“How many people of colour, how many people of colour, on the day after the referendum with a sense of dread because of what had happened “Ultimately our country had chosen to listen to Boris Johnson, someone who has a track record of racist commentary, of giving credence to racism.”Despite his bizarre claims, the leadership hopeful admitted some of his own family voted to leave the EU.He said: Now that doesn’t mean that every single person that voted for Brexit is a racist, some of my family voted for Brexit but I think there were drivers within that campaign that certainly were very unsavoury and what I would call racist.”The radical leftie also called for the Royal Family and private schools to be abolished.His comments sparked fury among Brexiteers, with Sir Iain Duncan Smith labelling them “breathtaking absurdity”.He said: “He’s saying this about . million people.“The present Labour party does not understand why people have turned away from them.“The Labour party think they won the election but were finally let down by the British people at the end.”Passionate Brexiteer Steve Baker also blasted the leadership contenders claims.He said: “Clive’s hysterics are not just wrong, they obviously didn’t work with the British public, who are far too sensible for this rubbish.“It’s time to pull together, not sow more ision.”

title: michael fabricant letter to queen
story: In his letter to Her Majesty, Michael Fabricant says Buckingham Palace’s dilemma over what to do with Prince Harry “could be turned into a huge triumphthey accept his proposal.And the MP says that far from being “a cause for sorrow,” the decision by Harry and Meghan to quit the Firm and relocate to Canada could instead be “a wonderful opportunity for both the Royal Family and our country at large”.He says the move would also bolster the monarchy’s reputation internationally and give the UK “an enormous boost in soft power at an important juncture for our country as we depart the European Union”.He points to a poll that found six in ten Canadians were in favour of Prince Harry becoming Governor General of Canada.Mr Fabricant says Prince Harry would be “well-suited to this role” due to his “valiant service in the Army” and charity work.The Governor is formally appointed by the Queen on the advice of the Canadian PM to carry out her constitutional and ceremonial duties in the country.The current incumbent is Julie Payette, an astronaut from Quebec, who has served since .Governors usually serve for five years but there is no constitutional timeframe.Mr Fabricant says that while she has done a “sterling job,” nobody has the “same kind of box office appeal that Harry does”.In his letter he writes: “As Your Majesty will no doubt be aware, the decision by the Duke and Duchess of Sussex to step back from their royal duties to spend more time in North America has caused quite a stir among your loyal subjects.“While many disapprove of this, may I make the case that this can in fact be a wonderful opportunity for both the Royal Family and our country at large  A challenge could be turned to a huge triumph.”He adds: “While their methods and approach to royal duties may not always fall in line with tradition, there is no doubting that Harry and Meghan are seen by many of the younger generation as symbols of a new, modern, vibrant monarchy.”“Installing Harry as Governor General would not only bolster support for the Monarchy internationally, but also provide Canada, and by extension the United Kingdom, an enormous boost in soft power at an important juncture for our country as we depart the European Union.“There is also little doubt that Harry would be well-suited to this role.His valiant service in the Army, as well as his numerous charity works, give him more than enough experience to serve as Your Majestys representative to Canada.”As Your Majesty will no doubt be aware, the decision by the Duke and Duchess of Sussex to step back from their royal duties to spend more time in North America has caused quite a stir among your loyal subjects.While many disapprove of this, may I make the case that this can in fact be a wonderful opportunity for both the Royal Family and our country at large  A challenge could be turned to a huge triumph.The departure of the Sussexes from these shores need not be a cause for sorrow. A recent Postmedia poll in Canada found that over % there were in favour of Prince Harry becoming the Governor General of Canada.The poll also showed that it was younger Canadians who would be most in favour of such a move, and that even in the generally French republican province of Quebec, almost half would also support this.The current Governor General, Julie Payette, who has been in post since , has done a sterling job. However, neither she, nor anyone  who has previously held this position, possess the same kind of box office appeal that Harry does.While their methods and approach to royal duties may not always fall in line with tradition, there is no doubting that Harry and Meghan are seen by many of the younger generation as symbols of a new, modern, vibrant monarchy.Installing Harry as Governor General would not only bolster support for the Monarchy internationally, but also provide Canada, and by extension the United Kingdom, an enormous boost in soft power at an important juncture for our country as we depart the European Union.Procedurally, there would be few barriers to making this a reality. title: keir starmer posh remainer leader
story: It was this “Posh Trot” Remainer who drove a bulldozer through Labour’s so-called Red Wall and cleared the path for Boris Johnson’s invasion of its northern heartlands.It was Starmer’s campaign for a chaotic second referendum that persuaded millions of working-class supporters to vote Tory for the first time and condemn Labour to the political wilderness.Not surprisingly, Starmer’s critics now wonder why this proven loser is in pole position to run their party.Some point the finger at Gordon Brown quietly rallying supporters to the cause.The ex-PM and his protegé have been close since Starmer’s controversial reign as Director of Public Prosecutions from  to .Starmer, despite his reputation for defending human rights, is not above sly ploys.There is nothing wrong with being wealthy — except among the Momentum voters he needs to seize Labour’s crown. Perhaps this explains why his Wikipedia entry has just been doctored to delete his status as a “millionaire”. Not me, guv, protests Starmer.He is also weirdly reluctant to declare where he stands on the political spectrum. Is he a Corbynite or a Blairite or a bit of both  “I don’t have the names of former leaders tattooed on my head,” snfs the man named at birth after the first leader of the Labour Party.This knight of the realm, who played violin at fee-paying Reigate Grammar School alongside Fatboy Slim, claims a humble background as the son of a toolmaker.“I know what it’s like,” he insists, asraised in a cardboard box.Well, I went to the same school when it was a “bog-standard” state grammar. So we can compete. But when the field is tilted and people start making up the rules … thataposs when the problems start. Last week, as Samira Ahmed won her equal pay claim against the BBC, we saw just how the game is rigged. Ahmed, who hosts the viewer feedback programme, Newswatch, was paid seven times less than Jeremy Vine, who presents a similar programme, Points of View. Seven Times! The BBC justied this discrepancy by claiming that the Points of View needed a “cheeky” presenter with a “glint in his eye”. That’s some glint! The BBC clearly knew what they meant. They paid enough for it, I on the other hand wasn’t so sure. But when subjected to the critical eye of an impartial jury the rationale clearly fell apart. “Jeremy Vine read the script from the autocue,” their devastating assessment read. “He read it in the tone in which it was written. If it told him to roll his eyes, he did. It did not require any particular skill or experience to do that….We have dficulty in understanding what [the BBC] meant by a ‘glint in the eye’ and how that translated into a ‘skill’ or ‘experience’ for the job.  How does one acquire such a skill or experience ” The point here is not to do down Jeremy Vine. I like him and his competence was not on trial.  His pay is not going down. It is to try and decipher why a woman would be paid so much less for essentially the same work. How could Ahmed’s talents be so undervalued  How could her talents be so invisible  What were they thinking  How could this happen  As the shadow minister for equalities I know nobody in the BBC was sitting there thinking - “How can we pay a woman less than a white man for the same job ” This was not a deliberate ploy. Discrimination, nowadays, rarely works like that. True, there are people who think little of women and denigrate people of colour. One of them lives at Number . Imagine how the media would have treated meI had been caught having three affairs, one love child,  refused to tell anyone how many children I had and talked about white people the way Boris Johnson has talked about black people and Muslims. But beyond that gilded world, where a pliant media look past the prejudice of the privileged, many of us work in institutions that simply haven’t caught up with how the way the world has changed. They are driven by the same impulses and reflexes as they were when women were supposed to stop working once they had kids and black people were rarely seen and never heard. Ahmed was effectively caught in a system that devalues women and people of colour, failing to see their potential and to understand their contributions as valid.  We are judged by dferent standards. The verdict could leave the BBC with a bill running into the millions as similar claims by other female staff now come to the fore. But the cost to their reputation. This is the nation’s broadcaster. People expect more from the BBC. Ahmed certainly did. The bravery and tenacity it took for her to pursue this course of action cannot be underestimated. “I love working for the BBC,” she said.  “No woman wants to have to take action against their own employer.” Tomorrow I hope to make it onto the ballot for the Labour Party Deputy Leadership.  tle I’m certainly qualied. I’m the first elected black woman in Britain to ever become a minister I’ve had responsibilities under two Labour prime ministers Tony Blair and Gordon Brown and I have served in Jeremy Corbyn’s shadow cabinet.  In  I won my seat from the Lib Dems with a .% swing - the biggest swing to Labour in the country. You would think that would be enough to get me on the ballot and then let Labour members decide whether I’m up to the job. My potential opponent does. Angela Rayner has generously called for some of those who nominated her to switch their vote to me so that we can have a full debate about the future of the party, just as I nominated Jeremy Corbyn, even though I initially supported Andy Burnham, because I thought it was important that his voice was heard. The field of Labour candidates standing for the leadership and deputy leadership, has never been more erse. It remains to be seen whether the candidates that the Parliamentary Labour Partyselect to put before the membership will reflect that.

title: new black labour mps say
story: NewsNew black Labour MPs say they need name tags as people keep getting them mixed upAbena Oppong-Asare and Florence Eshalomi say they have both already been called the wrong name and mistaken for other politicians since they joined the Houses of Commons in the December electionShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsFlorence Eshalomi has been confused for other black MPs " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailTwo newly-elected black Labour MPs have joked that they need name tags after sharing their experiences of being taken for someone . Abena Oppong-Asare and Florence Eshalomi both won their seats in December and have spoken out about attitudes in Parliament. Oppong-Asare, who is MP for Erith and Thamesmead, says she was also handed a bag by a Tory MP to look after because he thought she was someone .  She was also confused with other black women in the Commons. In a Twitter thread she explained: The other day I was outside the @HouseofCommons chamber talking to @DrRosena [Rosena Allin-Khan] and one of the Tory MPs walked straight to me to put his bag in my hands asking me to look after it #ThisIsWhyRepresentationMattersShe said: In my first week someone came up to me confusing me with another black MP. I said no I’m the other black sista from Erith and Thamesmead Labour . He raised he eyebrows and said wow there more of you. Adding: Last week another MP from another party came over to chat to me about a convo we had before Xmas. I realised a few mins in she got me confused with another #BlackSistaShe concluded: Iaposm thinking I might need to write my name on my forehead as I think some people are really struggling to tell the dference. Once Ms Oppong-Asare started posting her experiences fellow newbie Florence Eshalomi joined in the discussion. She tweeted: Girl I also got confused for another black sista MP as we were coming out of the voting lobby...... but I have to admit it was by a fellow Labour MP. Guess we all need to wear massive name tags right.  Their tweets prompted an outpouring of support. Leadership candidate Jess Phillips remarked: Abena you are already making your mark in Parliament as a brilliant force. This experience speaks to so much that is wrong with our parliament and our institutions. You should find the Tory who did it next week and ask them to hold your bag and throw your coat in too! But Rayner faced a backlash for her response to Florence Eshalomi. She commented: “Me and Jess Phillips often have the same problem because we both have an accent despite them being totally dferent.” Some users accused her of comparing their experiences with her experience of being mistaken for other MPs with a strong regional accent. She later deleted the message, saying her remark y had been poorly judged, adding: “As I would in no way compare that to my colleagues who are mistaken due to the colour of their skin.”  It comes as both Clive Lewis and Dawn Butler, who do not yet have the numbers they need to get on the leadership and deputy leadership ballots, have suggested that the Parliamentary Labour Party has an issue with racism. Butler, who has been an MP since  has previously spoken of being mistaken for a cleaner in parliament.

title: tory mp says poor people
story: NewsTory MP says poor people are fattest and need to be taught to eat healthilySir Desmond Swayne said families on benefits who are forced to turn to foodbanks should learn to do food shopping “more cost effectively”ShareCommentsByAdam Aspinall:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsSir Desmond Swayne said families on benefits who are forced to turn to foodbanks should learn to do food shopping “more cost effectively” " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA Tory MP has been blasted for saying poor people are the “fattest” and need to be taught how to shop more healthily. Sir Desmond Swayne said families on benefits who are forced to turn to foodbanks should learn to do food shopping “more cost effectively”. Writing in a local newspaper he argued foodbanks are an “important contribution” to the welfare system. But checks should be made to see how families “actually spend” their benefits, the MP for New Forest West, in Hampshire added. The former aide to ex-PM David Cameron said: “The shocking statistic is one in five of our children is obese by the time they leave primary school and this disproportionately affects those children in the lowest household incomes. To put it bluntly : the poorest are amongst the fattest. “The conclusion I draw is their families need, in addition to welfare payments, help with how to shop more cost effectively and healthily.”
