title: major-junction-work-start-a1-near-queen-margaret-university
story: The work, due to start in April next year, has generally been welcomed but there are fears that traffic from the development will clog up Musselburghrsquos road network.The QMU A junction improvements, approved by East Lothian Council planners under delegated powers, follow two planning applications from Persimmon Homes for more than  hectares of land surrounding the university, at Craighall, already getting the go-ahead.Detailed planning permission for  new homes was approved for part of the site north of the A at Monktonhall.It is anticipated that the majority of the remaining , homes will be built south of the A.There are also plans to build a new primary school south of the A for the future Craighall community, where there will also be three full-size sports pitches and new lsquocycle superhighwaysrsquo created using a railway line which runs under the dual carriageway.The masterplan for the land, which stretches from Stoneybank and Newcraighall in the north down past the village of Old Craighall, shows about  hectares of the land south of the A set aside for housing and the school, with a further  hectares for employment.North of the A, more than  hectares have been earmarked for housing and an innovation park supporting research work at the university.Land has also been set aside for the possible expansion of Musselburgh Railway Station in future.A planning report stated that junction completion works, put forward by East Lothian Council, would involve the construction of new slip-roads to the A northbound carriageway which would meet in a roundabout, providing arms to the development areas and a link road to the existing junction at QMU.The existing junction A southbound slip-roads would be retained and enhanced with extended auxiliary lanes to ease traffic movement. The existing junction in front of QMU would also be modied from a give-way ghost island T-junction to a signalised junction with greater capacity to hold turning traffic.The proposed scheme would, through the provision of an underpass beneath the A and slip roads to the northbound carriageway of the A, enable traffic movement from QMU and the new development to access the A northbound directly.Street lighting is proposed to be installed extended to include the new section of Queen Margaret Drive which would be provided under the A to the proposed roundabout junction. Street lighting would also be provided on the new slip roads.The proposals also include foot and cycle paths, two SUDS ponds, mitigation planting of native woodland to the main junction, structure tree planting, marginal planting to the proposed SUDS areas, and more ornamental planting to the areas near the QMU campus.Colin Beattie, Musselburgh MSP, said: ldquoWhile I welcome improvements to the road system which will accommodate the exciting new business developments around QMU, I am less enthusiastic about the huge expansion of housing, albeit much-needed, adjacent to QMU.ldquoThey will substantially increase the traffic on that stretch of road. Hopefully the improvements will manage that well.ldquoI continue to have concerns about developments being put in place with inadequate attention to overall infrastructure needs and the impact on surrounding residents.Barry Turner, spokesman for Musselburgh Conservation Society, added: ldquoThough we do not want this amount of housing in this location, we hope that the improved junction will channel much of the traffic generated onto the A and away from Musselburgh.ldquoThere are already serious traffic problems at the bottom end of Monktonhall Road and at the Tesco roundabout. Evenjust some of the traffic from the development around QMU comes this way to access facilities in Musselburgh, we fear the road system will clog up totally.ldquoWe have no problem with the junction improvements. Our issue is with the amount of housing proposed, which is totally inappropriate.Councillor John Williamson added: ldquoThe planned developments will technically be part of Musselburgh, although the vast majority of the new housing will be on the western side of the A with the only direct access to Musselburgh itself, as far as Irsquom aware, restricted to public transport and cycle pedestrian access.ldquoThe only full vehicle access will be via Newcraighall or Old Craighall Roundabout, which means that it will be dficult for the new communities to feel an integral part of Musselburgh.A spokesperson for QMU said: ldquoWe welcome news of the approval of planning permission for the A QMU road junction which will help unlock the full potential of the site for the development of the Innovation Park.ldquoQMU chose to move to East Lothian partly because of the opportunities to work with employers to develop the land immediately adjacent to the new campus.ldquoThe decision is the latest in a series of important milestones that have brought us a step closer to progressing plans for sustainable economic development.

title: bid-test-rocket-engines-former-cockenzie-power-station-site-rejected
story: Skyrorarsquos bid to set up a base on where the sitersquos former coal handling plant stood had caused a ision between neighbouring community councils and saw nearly  objections lodged with East Lothian Council.And at a meeting of the local authorityrsquos planning committee last Wednesday, the proposal was rejected against the advice of council officials after planning convenor Councillor Norman Hampshire branded the development a ldquobad neighbour.Mr Hampshire told fellow committee members that he was concerned that allowing Skyrora to test rocket engines on the land, which is central to the councilrsquos future economic plans, could put other investors off.He said: ldquoThis is not a good neighbour ndash it is a bad neighbour development and my concern is this may deter potential investors from taking on development at the Cockenzie site.Skyrora had lodged an application to create a rocket engine testing site on the land, which is owned by the local authority, with plans to carry out five -second tests each month.But while it applied for temporary use of the site for five years, Skyrora told the planning committee that it envisaged the possibility of not just expanding its presence in the community but potentially bringing a manufacturing facility, described as the size of an Ikea store, to the area.And while Prestonpans Community Council supported the move as offering potential for jobs and the economy, neighbouring Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council objected.At the planning committee meeting last week, Bryan Hickman, chairman of Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council, recalled a public meeting in the summer which attracted several hundred people.He said: ldquoVirtually everyone who was there was against it ndash ranging from our youngest residents to pensioners.ldquoThe feeling, rightly or wrongly, in the community is that they do not want it.During the council meeting, residents raised concerns about the storage of key elements of fuel on the site for days prior to testing, as well as the impact of burning kerosene into the atmosphere.While Skyrora insisted that the engine tests would be a ldquoclean burn producing mainly water, resident and biochemist Dr Brian Hall told the committee that he estimated about , litres of carbon dioxide and carbon monoxide could be released during each -second test.Calum Miller, on behalf of Prestonpans Community Council, urged councillors to approve the plans, pointing out that the power station site had lain empty now for six years.He told them: ldquoThe council has the opportunity with this Skyrora application to dispel the myth that we are too remote from Edinburgh to attract business.Ward councillors Fiona OrsquoDonnell, Lachlan Bruce and Neil Gilbert did not support the application.Ms OrsquoDonnell said that the impact on local amenity would be unacceptable and spoke of the ldquohigh level of public concern from constituents about the proximity of the test site to housing ndash the nearest of which was estimated at  metres away.Councillors rejected the planning application by six votes to two.The decision was welcomed by Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council chairman Mr Hickman, who said: ldquoThe community is very pleased about the decision as expressed on social media and meeting residents as I go about.ldquoI felt that we presented a strong case against the application.ldquoThe councillors present gave a fair and balanced summary before coming to their decision. The community thanks the ward councillors who called in the application.ldquoIf this did not go before the committee, it would have been approved by East Lothian Council planning department.Brian Weddell, chairman of Prestonpans Community Council, said that he hoped the council would now turn attention to calls for a cruise port at the former power station site, which has been supported by his members. He said: ldquoI am disappointed that local ward councillors went against the advice of their council officers on this planning application.ldquoHopefully this will focus East Lothian Council councillors and officials on pushing forward the cruise port initiative to secure much-needed jobs in East Lothian.And his community council colleague Mr Miller criticised councillors for failing to listen to their officials.He said: ldquoIt was patently obvious that councillors on the planning committee couldnrsquot get their heads around the nuances of decibels and emissions.ldquoThey should have fallen back on advice from their own experienced officials. Instead, they repeated the junk science coming from cranks in Cockenzie.ldquoEach test would have generated the same emissions as a family car running for a year. The councillors who referenced a climate emergency in defence of their decision were only too happy to drive home from Haddington.ldquoAn ecosystem of space technology companies could have emerged in East Lothian based around the testbed.ldquoThe wilful ignorance of a few has pulled opportunity for the hands of young people in East Lothian.Derek Harris, from Skyrora, said he was disappointed by the decision of the planning committee.It is understood the company will take time to consider whether to appeal the decision.Mr Harris said: ldquoI would like to thank all the staff at East Lothian Council who helped with our application. I am disappointed by the decision but it went through the democratic process.

title: mum-gives-fresh-meal-kits-need-christmas
story: Jane Russell, , of Harlawhill Gardens, has been flooded with donations as well as appeals for help from families in the county since she posted on Facebook that she was willing to drop off the fresh meal kits.The mum-of-three was inspired to help those in need because only a few years ago she was struggling herself, and whilst she thinks foodbanks are great, she knows that some people can be hesitant to use them.She wanted to offer a mobile alternative for families, providing them with fresh food.Janersquos family have all got involved and have set up the Facebook page lsquoSunday fresh chicken dinner boxesrsquo so families can get in touch.Their meal kit includes: a fresh whole chicken, fresh herbs, potatoes, broccoli, carrots, onions, Yorkshire puddings, gravy granules and selection boxes or biscuits.Jane said: ldquoI never imagined that it would grow this big but since I posted on Facebook it has just snowballed.ldquoI wouldnrsquot be able to do all of this myself and so many people have offered to help out, which is amazing.ldquoWe now have four drivers helping and I keep coming home to bags of food and chickens on my doorstep.ldquoThe idea was originally that I would deliver them on a Friday so that the families would have everything necessary for Sunday dinner but wersquore now delivering Wednesday to Sunday.ldquoAnd we were only going to do this up until Christmas but we are going to extend it until after New Year because we know the foodbank closes for a period and wersquod like to help anyone struggling over that time.ldquoMy kids have been helping make the boxes up at night and my youngest two even dress up as elves to help.Jane who has two children at Preston Tower Primary School, Prestonpans, and one at Musselburgh Grammar School, has been inundated with requests from families in the county and where she even had a message from someone in the USA on social media who did not realise she was based in East Lothian.She is only able to deliver within the county and has been ldquoheartbroken to have to say no to some families but her act of kindness has inspired others to pick up the task of producing boxes for other areas.Jane is also fundraising to start up her Prestonpans-based charity The Young Minds Hub to help young people with mental health issues.To request a box, contact the Facebook page lsquoSunday fresh chicken dinner boxesrsquo.

title: former-depute-lord-lieutenant-receives-telegram-queen-diamond-wedding
story: Marlene, , and Stan, , married in  and have four children together ndash now aged between  and . They also have five grandchildren and two great-grandchildren, one of whom is just a few weeks old.The Port Seton couple had a surprise celebration with their loved ones at the Waterside Bistro in Haddington on Boxing Day and were joined by the Lord Lieutenant of East Lothian Michael Williams and deputy Lynn Marshall, who greeted Marlene with a huge bunch of flowers and her very own telegram from Her Majesty The Queen.Marlene told the Courier: ldquoIt was very exciting. I knew that at some point I would have got a telegram but with our anniversary being on Boxing Day, I didnrsquot know when it would be.Marlene, who has always been heavily involved in the community, said she was ldquopassionate about where she lives.She got involved with the villagersquos gala committee when her children were young and went on to serve Cockenzie  Port Seton Community Council for  years.She has also been the chair of Cockenzie and Port Seton In Bloom for  years and was the chair of the community centre advisory committee before there was even a Port Seton Centre.She is still on the management committee for the centre and said she never thought she would live to see the new sports hall that she has passionately campaigned for, which is due to be finished by August.Marlene met her husband Stan, who was living in Leith at the time, ldquoquite by accident, she said.ldquoStanrsquos friendrsquos mother had a hut at the [Seton Sands] caravan site and the boys used to come down at the weekends [from Edinburgh], she said.ldquoI was going down to buy cigarettes for my friend and Stan shouted something out of the window of a car at me, and afterwards we realised we worked quite close to each other.ldquoI worked at the McEwanrsquos brewery [in Fountainbridge] as a telephonist and Stan worked for the North British Rubber Company at the time.ldquoWe used to meet at lunchtime and then Stan got into the habit of coming to Port Seton every weekend. He would just happen to be at the bus station when I finished work with no bus fare.The couple, of Inglis Avenue, married a year later, when Marlene was  and Stan was .Stan worked at Cockenzie Power Station for  years and even helped with the construction of the site before it opened in .He joked: ldquoI helped build it and helped tear it down!Marlene said of their marriage: ldquoWe never thought we would have made it to this milestone. I remember my father saying: lsquoI will give you six months.rsquoldquoWe had a lot of hard times, we were young and foolish and hard up, but for some unknown reason we managed to take the kids on holiday every year and buy them their season tickets for the swimming pool. We had to save all year for them.ldquoFor the young, I would say not to marry young. Irsquom very proud that none of my children have followed in our footsteps.ldquoI would say [in marriage] it is important to always be mindful of one another and try to be toleranthellip never keep an argument going. It is too easy nowadays to walk away but you just have to keep going. I wanted to kill him some days and it was probably likewise but we have had a great le together.ldquoWe feel very lucky to have reached this age and that all of our children have got good lives, and their children are just a delight to have around.In their retirement, Marlene and Stan have travelled most of the Mediterranean and much of Europe together, and enjoy looking after their grandchildren, who all live in the county.

title: 10-signs-coercive-control-within-relationship
story: The offence of coercive control now recognises that domestic abuse can take several forms and is not strictly limited to physical violence.The changes outlaw a number of things that were not previously covered by existing laws.Now, laws have now been enforced in England and Wales, with the amendments making the following acts towards a partner illegal.. Sharing sexually explicit images of a partnerNew laws surrounding lsquorevenge pornrsquo make it illegal for someone to share intimate photographs of you with anyone, online or otherwise.. Restricting access to financesEventhey earn more money than you, the law says your partner cannot stop youfrom accessing cash within the relationship.. Putting you downPersistent name-calling, mocking and other forms of insulting behaviour are now illegal.. Stopping a partner from seeing friends or familyMonitoring or blocking of calls and emails, telling you where you can or cannot go, and preventing you from seeing your friends or relatives is nowagainst the law. IF your partner isolatesyou from the people you love, they could face the wrath of the law.. Scaring youYour partner might not physically assault you, butthey are doing enough to frighten you, they are committing an offence. That could include using their size to intimidate or breaking things around the house.. Threatening to reveal private things about youRepeated threats to reveal personal and private information is now classed asa form of abuse. It could include reveallingdetails about health or sexual orientation.. Putting tracking devices on your phoneIt is illegal under the new legislation to ldquomonitor a person using online communication tools or spyware.. Being extremely jealousPersistent accusation of cheating and ldquoextreme jealousy, including possessiveness and ridiculous accusations of cheating all come under the new legislation.. Forcing you to obey their rulesThe CPS saysa partner isforced to abide by stringent rules set by a partner, it could mean they are committing a crime.. Controlling what you wearYour partner taking control over any part of your le is highlighted in the new legislation, including restricting who you see and where you go.Controlling what you wear or how you look could also now be grounds for prosecution under the changes.

title: tims-tales-power-sea
story: I CAN remember, quite vividly, sitting on the Greenhills by Prestonpans when I was around  years old looking out to the sea. I was alone and deep in thought. I cannot remember now exactly what the issue was, but something had happened that seemed to be unfair, and it had made me angry.It was a windy and cold day. The tide was in and the waves rolling and crashing created a kind of meditative sound. I donrsquot know how long I sat there, as time seemed to dissolve as I listened to the sea, and smelt the salt air.Later I walked by the shore, again alone, and I remember how my mood had changed.My memory of that day fades at this point: I cannot recall what happened as I ed home. But clearly the sea had done its job in calming my emotional state.Memories are not like books on a shelf which we can take out and look at, and then . Our memories are really about emotions rather than happenings. We connect to the emotions first, our brain then does a search for the events associated with the emotion. Songs, smell, sounds and places can trigger emotion which then leads to associations with actual events.So itrsquos the emotion attached to events which will mark it as signicant. Thatrsquos why we remember the unusual moments more than the everyday ones. We remember the events when our emotions were aroused, either positively or negatively.That day I was angry. The sea was pretty much on our doorstep, so it was probably an obvious place to go to be alone, away from my siblings, to rage at the injustice I felt. But it was a good choice, because the sea has a powerful ability to heal.There seems to be a sense by some that the sea is a place to go only when itrsquos sunny and warm. In fact, the gts of the sea are given all year round, and it is winter time, or a time of storm and wind, that the sea becomes a powerful place to find naturersquos healing.How lucky we are to live in a county where we have  miles of coastline, much of it close to communities and accessible. Those with a sense of adventure and physical ability to do so can find parts of the coast to themselves, even in busy times.But as I learnt all those years ago, the sea can speak to us directly. Simply sitting by it, or walking along the shore while sharing our thoughts, can be a powerful form of mental as well as physical healing.Some take this a step further by bathing in the sea on a regular basis ndash yes, even in the winter. There are real benefits to swimming in a cold sea, both in terms of mental and physical health. But I think it helpsothers do it with you, as an encouragement! The Loony Dooks which take place at North Berwick, Dunbar and where around the coast should be a weekly event, not a yearly one!But we donrsquot need to be in the sea to feel its benefits, just by it and connected to it mentally, and yes, spiritually. This is a serious point. We have an epidemic of mental health issues, and while there is no one simple explanation or solution, we need to understand the signicance of our disconnection from nature and its impact on our mental health. Spending time by the sea is a tonic for body and mind.I think we felt this last week when we headed for the rocks at North Berwick on Boxing Day. It was here that Robert Louis Stevenson played as a boy and discovered a small cave in which he imagined tales of pirates and smugglers. The island of Fidra, said to be his inspiration for Treasure Island, can be seen further along the coast.The tide was in, so it wasnrsquot possible to see the cave. But in scrambling over the rocks, discovering other things and sitting by the waves, the sea did its magic for our family and myself. The waves were crashing andyou studied how they hit the rocks you could see how the hand of the sea had carved them in certain ways.We sat and explored there ndash not noticing the nippy wind ndash for a good hour. It was an overcast afternoon and darkness fell soon. But the walk along the beach to the town for a hot chocolate was the final part of the therapy!Our coastline is a gt for us and we need to use it, and respect it, more. The beaches, coves and clfs of our county are a true treasure. Try spending more time with them, listening and experiencing the sea, walking or sitting with it.I promise you, you will feel better, and have a story to tell.Happy New Year.

title: new-mcbrave-games-event-held-musselburgh
story: The action-packed event, called McBrave Games, promises participants a uniquely Scottish experience with events such as tug orsquo war, tossing the caber, putting the shot, the hill race, weechinrsquo the welly and a Highland fling.There will also be a Scottish twist on challenges along the km obstacle course to test participants.The event takes place on Saturday, May , at Newhailes House.Participants can take on the challenge as a solo entrant or enter as a clan of four with colleagues or friends to battle it out to become the laddie or lassie of McBrave Games.Co-founders Jo Dytch and Andrew Hastings are confident the creativity and innovation behind the event will encourage entrants to try something new in .Jo and Andrew bring with them more than  yearsrsquo combined experience in the mass participation space on large-scale events such as Race for Le, Tough Mudder and the -mile Cateran Yomp.Commenting on the inspiration behind the event, Jo said: ldquoScotland is an inspiring and magical place. Bringing the Highland Games to everyone and making it accessible seems only right. ldquoAndrew added: ldquoThe idea of combining an epic obstacle race with the Highland Games really got us excited.ldquoIt has taken us the best part of a year to get the event from a concept ready to go.ldquoWe are both big believers in innovation and the McBrave Games is a new idea that takes the familiar and gives it a unique twist.Participants can register online.

title: double-yellow-lines-planned-haddingtons-long-stay-car-park
story: East Lothian Council has confirmed it will bring forward plans to crack down on bad parking at the free site near to Tesco in Haddington town centre.The move follows a controversial bid by the local authority to introduce a new alternative car park outside the town centre.A bid for a ldquotransportation hub to the east of the town was put forward last month and sparked an angry reaction from town centre traders, who fear it will put people off shopping in the centre.The council has launched a public consultation on Haddington town centre parking and transportation and this included an exhibition which showed images of people parking outwithallocated spaces in the current -space long-stay car park which is linked to Tescorsquos own short-stay customer car park.Under the heading ldquoindiscriminate parking, the images showed cars and vans parked on kerb corners and other unmarked areas of the car park which were not designated bays.It was, the council said, a way to illustrate the need for additional car parking in Haddington.Now the council has confirmed it is planning to introduce new traffic regulations which will stop people from parking outside spaces in the packed car park.A spokesperson said: ldquoA report will be presented to our cabinet meeting in January with proposals to introduce double yellow lines to the long-stay car park.This is to improve safety and reduce damage to the kerbs and road surfaces caused by indiscriminate parking.ldquoFollowing cabinet, the proposals will be subject to a statutory process before the necessary regulations could be introduced.Last October, the council introduced similar restrictions in its own staff car park at John Muir House, Haddington, which lies a short distance from the long-stay facility.That saw dozens of workers receive fines, from the team of private parking wardens employed by the council, for ignoring new yellow lines in their own car park.The long-stay car park in Haddington is on land owned by East Lothian Council and accessed through the adjoining short-stay car park attached to the neighbouring Tesco supermarket.

title: east-lothian-council-electric-bridge-closure
story: The Electric Bridge in Musselburgh was built to carry traffic involved in the construction of Cockenzie Power Station in the s and regularly opened on racedays in the town as traffic flooded in.However,ScottishPower announced last week that it would be closed from January , with no plans to re-open in the future.The company has been in discussions with East Lothian Council, which has already bought the majority of the former power station land, over the future ownership of the bridge.Those discussions seem to have hit the buffers after Musselburgh councillor Andrew Forrest told a meeting this week the future use of the bridge was ldquoout of everybodyrsquos hands.Reacting to calls from Musselburgh Racecourse general manager Bill Farnsworth for the council to take responsibility for the bridge, Mr Forrest told a meeting of Musselburgh Racing Associated Committeit was not down to them.He said: ldquoIt is their [ScottishPower]train set and they will play with it however they want to play with it.The Electric Bridge traditionally opened on race days at Musselburgh Racecourse to help with traffic through the busy town centre.When the power station closed in , the bridge, which spans the River Esk, was closed but an agreement was met with the racecourse, East Lothian Council and ScottishPower to open it for major events.At the MRAC meeting, racecourse general manager Bill Farnsworth said it was used until last year by the Musselburgh Riding of the Marches and was used by the Edinburgh Marathon as well as the racecourse.He described the decision by ScottishPower to close it as ldquodisappointing and said he had been told that ldquoScottishPower do not need it and East Lothian Council do not want it.Mr Farnsworth urged the local authority to try again to take ownership of the bridge, adding: ldquoWe are told the bridge is absolutely sound and in good order. It is a perfectlygood bridge that is being closed and we are urging councillors and the council to try and reach an agreement with ScottishPower.Howeve,r Mr Farnsworth was told that there was no reason why the racecourse itself could not approach ScottishPower to reach a separate agreement regarding opening the bridge in the future.

title: groundsman-almost-struck-replacing-divets-midway-race-musselburgh
story: The lsquonear-missrsquo incident occurredduring the Edinburgh Cup in September when groundstaff had been warned to remember the main race of the day would see the runners go round the course twice over the two-mile event.However, it appeared one of the workers forgot and was still replacing ets on the ground when the horses came round the bend towards him.It was only when he heard jockeys shouting at him to get out of the way that he managed to duck under the barriers to safety.Bill Farnsworth, racecourse general manager, said a stewards inquiry was launched after the incident and the British Horseracing Authority investigated ruling that all protocolhad been followed by the racecourse itself.The incident came to light at a meeting of Musselburgh Racing Associated Committee this week.Mr Farnsworth said: ldquoThe Edinburgh Cup is a two-mile race and our head groundsman warned all the groundstaff to remember they go round twice.ldquoOne of the groundsmen went out and obviously forgot it was a two-mile race.ldquoHe was busy knocking in the ets as horses came around the bend and jockeys had to shout at him.ldquoHe ducked off the track, it was a lsquonear missrsquo.He added that a similar incident at Ascot in November had seen that course fined nearly pound, by the British Horseracing Authority for not following the proper protocol before the race.Mr Farnsworth said: ldquoThe sport needs to decideit is safe for people to get on track during racing, it is weighing up the benefit of repairing the track with the risk. There is always a risk of human error.A spokesman for the British Horseracing Authority confirmed it had carried out an investigation into the incident during the Edinburgh Cup, adding: ldquoNo further action was required.

title: rugby-internationalist-recreates-st-marys-parish-church-gingerbread
story: St Maryrsquos Parish Church sits at the heart of Haddington and David Bergvall, with a little bit of help from partner Naomi Golightly and her five-year-old son Jackson Laing, has made his own, slightly smaller but definitely tastier, version!Naomi said: ldquoMy partner is from Sweden and he has been doing gingerbread house-making all his le.ldquoHe thought it would be an idea to make the church.ldquoIt was mostly him but me and my five-year-old son helped a little bit as well.The sweet version of the church measures a foot inand about six inches in height.David, who has represented Sweden in rugby union and plays for Haddington RFC, designed the walls and roof before taking it from the drawing board to the oven.The process took a couple of hours and Naomi, who works at Edinburgh Airport, said: ldquoWe have to roll everything out, cut each piece and put it in the oven.ldquoWe then need to wait for it to harden and stick it all together.ldquoThere were multiple trips back and forwards to the oven, which was my role.ldquoDavid cut templates out of cardboard and used that to cut round.ldquoIt was his mumrsquos recipe for the gingerbread house, so it is all homemade.Melted sugar was used to join the walls and roof together before it was decorated with a sprinkling of icing sugar to look like snow.The couplersquos creation attracted plenty of attention on social media, with David and Naomi making two versions of the edible structure.One has been given to Naomirsquos grandparents John and Val Golightly, who attend the church, with a second for her mum and dad Ruth Golightly and Colvin Denholm.David, who works for Alba Trees, has promised, though, that this is not the end of the gingerbread versions of the church.Instead, the -year-old from Umea,  kilometres to the north-east of Swedenrsquos capital city Stockholm, has vowed to make a ldquobigger and better version for next Christmas.Naomi, , said: ldquoDavid was drawing a picture for my grandparents for Christmas of the church, which is nice. As well as that, he decided to try to make the church.ldquoHe said this was just his first attempt and next year will be much better than this!

title: world-boxing-champion-josh-taylor-signs-top-rank-deal
story: The Prestonpans fighter, who last year became a double world champion at super lightweight, has signed a multi-year promotional agreement with Top Rank while also signing an advisory deal with MTK Global.He is set to make his debut on ESPN in the coming months.However, the move has drawn criticism from Cyclone Promotions, who Taylor signed with after turning professional.Taylor said: ldquoA new year, a new decade with lots of new beginnings and Irsquom starting this new decade with a big bang." was a huge year for me, but  looks set to be even bigger and Irsquom delighted to have signed a deal with Top Rank and ESPN and an advisory contract with MTK Global."I believe I am with the best team to take my career to the next level and I canrsquot wait to see what the future holds. I couldnt ask for a better partnership and know the future looks bright with this team lighting the way."Jamie Conlan, MTK Global professional development coordinator, added: ldquoJosh Taylor was  Fighter of the Year and won the Word Boxing Super Series in fantastic fashion with his win over Regis Prograis."Hes now linking up with Top Rank and MTK Global, so his sights are solely set on unying the ision and becoming a global star on both sides of the Atlantic.ldquoThis is a momentous partnership for all involved."MTK Global and Top Rank have a recent history of working together with title: dunbars-trial-20mph-speed-limit-set-become-permanent
story: The speed limit on the majority of streets to the north of the railway line was dropped from mph to mph in August .The change in speed limit was to be in place for  months before members of the public were given the chance to have their say on whether it should remain in place or revert back to the previous mph limit.A public consultation ndash both online and through leaflets posted through doors ndash was carried out to gather feedback.Ward councillor Norman Hampshire said the findings of the survey showed that the majority of people were in favour of keeping the reduced speed limit.He told Dunbar Community Council: ldquoThe survey results came back and  per cent of people were in support of it continuing.ldquoHowever, there were views that certain roads, distributor roads, as seen around the town should remain at  miles per hour.ldquoTransportation are reviewing the scheme and looking at roads they feel warrant ato mph. It will only be on major routes in the town but mph will continue because the survey results came back in favour of that.The final say on the scheme is likely to come at a council committee meeting, with a report currently being drawn up.Herbert Coutts, from the townrsquos community council, has been heavily involved in the move to see a reduced speed limit put in place.He said: ldquoI would be interested ndash presumably it is included within the report ndash to hear what the police evidence has been.ldquoThat is a big factor in all this.ldquoThe survey of public opinion is one thing but the police evidence and the results of the tests that were done in the same places where the council had recorded the speed of cars prior to the start of the trial [would be useful].A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council confirmed the report would look at ious issues, including the public consultation and the possibility of including or removing streets from the mph speed limit. title: call-donate-old-christmas-cards-recycled
story: The initiative has been organised by local environmentally friendly and anti-litter group Love Musselburgh.Founder Melanie Roccio said: ldquoThe cards that are donated will be passed on to craft groups and others in Musselburgh and surrounding areas who can use them to make new cards or gt tags. There is no official cut-off date but Irsquom sure most people will be getting rid of their cards in the next week or so.ldquoThe Christmas card recycling project is hopefully a way to give non-recyclable cards a second use before going to landfill. Irsquom hoping this will also highlight the issue of waste generated over Christmas time.ldquoAround one billion cards end up in UK bins every year and so many of those are covered in glitter or foil, making them non-recyclable. Choosing cards, wrapping paper and gt tags made from recyclable materials will convert a huge amount of waste from landfill.Drop-off points have been set up at the townrsquos Mint Fig, Blueberry, Wilsonrsquos of Musselburgh, East Coast restaurant and Ravelston House Hotel.Melanie said: ldquoItrsquos great to have local, independent businesses supporting this project and Irsquom really grateful to all of them.Anyone who would like cards to reuse should contact Love Musselburgh via Facebook.The group, along with Cycle Connections, has also organised a Big Clean  in the town on January , am-pm. Litter picking and graffiti removal will be targeted. There is a limited supply of equipment, so participants are asked to take along their own gloves and litter picking sticksthey have them. Anyone interested in getting involved in the event should meet at the Old Town Hall.Melanie said: ldquoWe will focus on that end of High Street, Kerrrsquos Wynd and Newbigging.ldquoWersquoll also be engaging with the public to highlight the issues concerning them. title: tims-tales-really-happened-dunglass-castle
story: ON THE edge of East Lothian, Dunglass Burn flows to the sea, having carved a dramatic ravine that forms the border between our county and Berwickshire.This natural wonder is often missed by those speeding along the main A, crossing over the modern bridge.I have written previously about the bridges here and the walk to the sea that takes you under them, and past the oldest one. This is a fascinating and picturesque structure from the th century, which lies semi-hidden amongst the trees that cling onto the steep sides of the slope.Dunglass is such a beautul area, and the ancient Dunglass Collegiate Church, dating from the th century, is one of its architectural jewels. Itrsquos open to the elements now, but well preserved and a popular place for weddings.The castle that once stood nearby is long gone. A more modern house sits on the spot where a mansion once stood, and before that the castle. Being on the main route south, the castle inevitably saw action during the ious times of war with England, being burned and damaged on a number of occasions in the s.But in August , the castle was effectively blown up in a huge explosion, and a version of events emerged which placed the blame on a vengeful servant called Edward Paris.It was a time of war and religious rage. Thomas the nd Earl of Haddington was leading a Covenanting force charged with defending this important route from the south, as the Covenanting army had entered England a few days earlier. He had established his force at Dunglass Castle, an obvious strategic location, to defend the armyrsquos rear.On that fateful day, August , , he was said to be in conversation with some fellow nobles when a huge explosion erupted from the vaults, instantly demolishing the central part of the castle which became little more than a pile of debris.Thomas and many others were killed, their bodies pulled from the rubble. They had been crushed by the collapse of the walls in the explosion.History has repeatedly recorded the names of the nobles killed on that day, but there were many others, as the castle was busy and full of people. Fty-four unnamed lsquocommon servantsrsquo were killed, and more than  other people badly injured, some later dying of their injuries.Edward Paris was Thomasrsquos servant and he has been blamed for this tragedy. The th-century writer Andrew Stevenson claimed Edward had the keys to the vault in which huge amounts of gunpowder had been stored, and he had been ldquoseduced by the enemies of the covenant to commit this act. He was an Englishman and another account says he was incensed at derogatory remarks made by Thomas about his countrymen.Irsquove always thought this explanation never really had the ring of truth. It was initially deemed an accident, and the story of Edwardrsquos role emerged later, instigated by a writer called William Lithgow, a man who had certain axes to grind. In one account, Edward is said to have thrust a hot poker into the gunpowder or set fire to it. The detail of this is suspect in itself, for who survived as a witness to this act  I suspect that a dreadful accident, possibly caused by incompetence and carelessness, was turned into a deliberate act of vengeance as it made a more useful explanation.Of course, it is very possible that Edward was offended or annoyed at things said by his master, and perhaps he mentioned this at some stage, later to be used as evidence of his guilt. But in truth, most servants will have seen or heard things which will have offended them, it was a part of their job.Imagineservants had been able to write and publish the things they had overheard and seen, what dferent historical narratives we would have!Motives for wanting to interpret the cause of the explosion in this way can be guessed at. It was a time of atrocity and massacre, with religious, political and national hatreds. Who was responsible for the dangerous stockpiling of the gunpowder in such a manner  It seems just too easy to blame a disgruntled servant. Even later, when writing up this period, religious and political loyalties influenced interpretation.If Edward Paris really did venture down to the vaults of Dunglass Castle on that fateful day, with the intention of committing suicide in order to kill his master, along with dozens of others, then he must have been infected with a deep hatred, as well as a total disregard for the lives of his fellow servants and his own.The truth is we will never know what really happened. But Edward Paris is a servant whose name we know. Countless numbers of so-called lsquocommon servantsrsquo whose lives and fates are deemed unimportant by history remain unrecorded just as the things they witnessed remain absent from our history books.Irsquove often thought it would be fascinating to meet Edwardrsquos ghost and ask him what really happened on that day.Silly idea, of course, but you never know.

title: public-exhibition-held-plans-revive-dunbars-east-beach
story: Dunbarrsquos East Beach, which hosts the townrsquos annual Loony Dook, was once a magnet for tourists but the disappearance of its golden sands over the years due to coastal erosion has led to fewer visitors.East Lothian Council has already been given permission for the first phase of work on the beach, which it is hoped will help sandwhile also protecting the shore.A public exhibition detailing plans for a second phase of work ndash and the project overall ndash takes place in Dunbarrsquos Bleachingfield Centre on Monday afternoon.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of the townrsquos community council, explained the desire to see the beach restored to how it was previously.She said: ldquoIt has been a long-held ambition.ldquoPeople reminisce about how wonderful the beach was and there has been a lot of disappointment that it has been so rocky for so long.Dave Northcott, East Lothian Council structural engineer and project leader, visited the community council shortly before Christmas to outline the plans.Consent is already in place for the construction of a breakwater at the southern end of East Beach.Refurbishment of the existing groyne at the same end of the beach has also been approved, alongside the placement of rock armour at the toe of the seawall. A marine licence is in place until the end of May, with work to be complete before then.At the same time, plans are being drawn up for a second phase of work, which would see the creation of a breakwater at the northern end of the beach.A marine licence will be needed for that piece of work, with the hope that could be in place before the end of May to allow work to simply continue from the first phase.If that is not possible, the contractor will leave the site andat a later date to construct the northern breakwater.Mrs Swan, who is also chairwoman of Dunbar Shore and Harbour Neighbourhood Group, encouraged people to head along to the public exhibition, which takes place between pm and pm.Those in attendance can speak to the consultants and East Lothian Council about the plans.Mrs Swan added: ldquoI think it is really, really important for people to come to the exhibition for two reasons.ldquoOne is to understand the thinking that has gone into the regeneration project and the other one is to become aware of the impact it might have on them during the construction weeks because it is going to be at least six weeks and it could run into months.ldquoThe nature of the breakwater is they are built of huge rocks, between three and six tonnes, and they are all coming from the quarry at Markle. There will be heavy vehicles moving through the town over an extended period of time.

title: long-serving-haddington-gp-retires-42-years
story: Dr Ross Langlands has been a familiar face to people with all sorts of ailments in Haddington and surrounding villages for more than  years.On December , he was joined by colleagues at the townrsquos Lammermuir Medical Practice for a special lunch to mark his retirement.He said: ldquoIrsquom quite ambivalent.ldquoIt has been quite hard to say cheerio to folk that I have looked after for a long time.ldquoI have had lots of cards and presents as well.ldquoIt has really been quite nice but quite sad in some ways.Dr Langlands previously worked in Bangour Village Hospital, West Lothian, as well as in the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh and the Royal Northern Infirmary in Inverness, but it is Haddington that he has called home.He said there had been plenty of changes since he started working as a GP in East Lothian in the late s.ldquoA fair few people did not have as many telephones in those days, or as many cars, said Dr Langlands.ldquoThere were many more house calls then and I used to have a sort of rota where I would go out to Garvald on a Tuesday.ldquoSomebody would be waiting at the edge of the village to flag me down and tell me who I needed to see it was quite quaint.Dr Langlands, who has four children ndash Alasdair, Niall, Caitlin and Angus ndash was initially based on Haddingtonrsquos Church Street with one other doctor.The small building had two rooms ndash a waiting room-cum-secretaryrsquos room and a consultant room.That all changed in  when the medical centre was moved to Newton Port, with the building extended to cope with an increasing population.Now, the medical centre is home to more than a dozen doctors, as well as nursing staff, with Tyne, Lammermuir and Orchard practices all under one roof.Dr Langlands highlighted how medicine had changed over the decades ndash in years gone by he did home deliveries and ulcers were treated with surgery rather than medication.However, the -year-old is not planning to simply sit with his feet up at home in Haddington, alongside we Debbie Strachan, who is a GP at Whitesands Medical Practice in Dunbar.He said: ldquoI think I feel like I would like some time for myself while I am still reasonably fit and able to pursue my wider interests.ldquoI did an Open University degree about  years ago and have kept up to date with geology.ldquoI plan to go on field trips and I enjoy gardening and cycling.ldquoI signed up for a couple of short courses and will be studying Spanish, English literature and politics.ldquoI will not be wearying, I donrsquot think.ldquoAlso, my we has got a long list of things to do.Stephanie Currie, practice manager at Lammermuir Medical Practice, described Dr Langlandsrsquo last day as ldquoan emotional occasion and that he would be ldquogreatly missed, definitely. She said: ldquoHe had lots of gts from patients handed in over the desk and gts from staff and doctors at all the practices.

title: stone-well-artworks-set-wallyford-housing-development
story: The public artwork project for the St Clements Wells site, planned by East Lothian Developments, was outlined to members of the villagersquos community council at its recent AGM.Susheila Jamieson and James Gordon, of Rachan Design, have designed large, chunky stone wells or circles with deep relief patterns, measuring six feet in diameter.They will be positioned vertically at both entrances to the new housing development on the east and west sides of Wallyford.Establishing a theme for the artwork involved carrying out research into the area and talking to local resident, historian and community council chairman Alister Hadden.Mr Hadden, who was re-elected community council chairman at the AGM, said St Clements Wells farm on the south side of Wallyford, at the foot of Farsquoside Hill, played a very important role in the local community as farming preceded coal mining, which became the big industrial employer.He added that the area had one of the biggest distilleries in Scotland, which was started in  by the Mylne family.Liz Curtis of the Scottish Place-Name Society added: ldquoClement was a Christian in first-century Rome. He was said to have been martyred at sea with an anchor round his neck and was therefore regarded as the patron saint of sailors. The cult of Clement spread to Scandinavia in about the th century and then to Britain.ldquoSt Clements Wells were probably named by Scandinavians living in the Tranent area.ldquoWe know they were here because of the presence of a powerful landholder of likely Scandinavian descent, Thor of Tranent, son of Swain, who is mentioned in many th-century charters. He held extensive lands in the area and granted the church of Tranent to Holyrood Abbey.Mr Hadden said: ldquoI am sure the new stone sculptures will add another piece of culture to our area when in place to the east and west sides of Wallyford alongside those we have already.ldquoThese include the mining memorial stone and coal hutches located at St Clements Housing estate just off Salters Road, the  mining stones at the Wallyford Bing, a community woodland depicting dferent mining scenes, and also the Battle of Pinkie Cleugh memorial at the west side of Wallyford.The shapes and patterns proposed relate to the themes of the wells, water, ripples, distilling, agriculture and the sense of space and open skies of the site as it is now. The overall idea is that the artwork reflects past, present and future heritages of the area.There will also be two St Clements Wells name  per entrance in stone, either hand carved or sandblasted.The idea for a stone village sign for Wallyford is also being explored in a design reflecting the ideas of crossing a river or burn by a ford.A spokesman for East Lothian Developments said: ldquoEast Lothian Developments are delighted to be working with Susheila and James to deliver ious artworks at St Clements Wells.ldquoThey have shown real enthusiasm and creativity with the ideas they have brought forward to capture something of the history of St Clements Wells and design pieces which we hope will do justice to the entrances of the development, and spark interest from all those who will pass them.ldquoWe were very grateful to the community council for their comments and input to the designs.Elaine Di Troia was appointed vice-chairman at the AGM, Sharon Jamieson secretary and Beryl Stevenson treasurer. Ann Patton, a member for three years, is also continuing her work as a community councillor.

title: Iain Macwhirter  Megxit means Megxit  It s time to abolish the monarchy
story: I couldnrsquot resist being drawn into the mysteries of palace le ndash the codes, the traditions, the high politics. It was brilliant public relations for the royal family. I found myself indulging in a new respect for Her Majesty herself,not the institution.Mrs Windsor has done a pretty good job in her six-and-a-bit decades on the throne, not just representing Britain but negotiating the dismantling of the British Empire in the s and s. Say what you like about Britainrsquos colonial past, but nothing became the Empire so much as the ending of it.She had the wisdom to realise, in the s, that to make the monarchy relevant, and justy the prodigious amounts of public money spent on its upkeep, there had to be a quid pro quo.The ldquoFirm, as she calls it, had to be seen to be ldquogiving something back through intense charitable activity and the grind of diplomatic intercourse. And, of course, simply ldquobeing there for the opening of bridges and hospitals, and for moments of national tragedy, like Aberfan.But the Queen is a product of a bygone age of deference, of patronage, of noblesse oblige. She embodies the virtues of duty, hard work and responsibility that defined the post-war ruling classes.These are anachronistic qualities in the age of celebrity. We now have an alternative royalty in the form of internet stars like the Kardashians, and Beyonce. This world has long held a fatal attraction to minor members of the royal brood, who aspire to the elite lestyle while lacking the means.Such has been the rather tawdry fate of Harry and Meghan. Megxit, and the disintegration of the Sussexesrsquo public image, would make a whole season of The Crown. Their departure from ldquosenior royal le has absolutely nothing to do with duty and everything to do with worldly aice.They clearly want to remain in the public eye, their celebrity wedding guest list confirmed that. They believe they can make a lot of money as influencers and sponsors. But they have found the duties and responsibilities of being part of the royal family uncongenial.In the words of Queen ndash the pop group that is ndash they want to break free. To which the British public says: fine. Do what you gotta to do. Polls show that the British public wish the Sussexes well in their new le.However, the deal is thatthey want to escape the paparazzi and the responsibilities of royalty, they must also give up its privileges. They must give up their royal titles and stop consuming vast amounts of public money.The renovation of their grace-and-favour home, Frogmore Cottage, cost the taxpayer pound. million. Their security costs around pound, a year. They receive millions from the revenues of royal estates, via Harryrsquos dad, Prince Charles.The financial taps should be turned off. There is no need, since Harryrsquos personal fortune is estimated at poundm and Meghan is also wealthy. To most of us this seems self-evident. And yoursquod expect Labour to be calling them out most loudly.The default position of the left used to be contempt for the flummery and waste of the royal family. They consume millions of pounds of public money that could be better used for foodbanks. The monarchy is regarded, rightly, as a feudal anachronism, the apex of privilege.But some Labour MPs, especially BAME ones, like Clive Lewis, seem to regard the Sussexes as a special kind of royalty. Far from condemning the behaviour of these soon-to-be ex-royals, theyrsquove been leaping to their defence. Meghan Markle is being portrayed as a victim rather than a social parasite. A victim of a racist media and a bigoted society.In a furious piece in the New York Times,columnist Afua Hirsch blamed deeply ingrained British racism for Meghanrsquos decision to ditch the Firm. ldquoHer treatment, she wrote, ldquohas proved what many of us have always known ... in this society racism will still follow you.Social media is fizzing with indignation at the allegedly racist treatment of Meghan. Oprah Winfrey has been fanning the flames across the pond. Racism has driven poor Meghan to seek refuge in Toronto.There is actually very little evidence of racism in the media treatment of Markle. The oft-quoted headline, ldquoshe was nearly straight out of Compton, may have been silly and wrong, but it wasnrsquot racist. The social and family background of a new member of the royal family is a legitimate matter of public interest.The instant sacking of disc jockey Danny Baker after his ldquomonkey tweet shows just how intolerant of racism the UK media has become. Criticism of Harry and Meghanrsquos hypocrisy in lecturing on the environment while relying on private jets is not racist.In the Sussexesrsquo resignation epistle there is no mention of racism. They clearly donrsquot like their treatment by the press. But their court actions against the media are about phone hacking and , not race.Meghan Markle was lionised by the press when she arrived on the scene three years ago. title: scottish-secretary-rules-indyref2-even-snp-win-holyrood-majority-2021
story: Alister Jack said a Tory government at Westminster would refuse to grant Holyrood the power to hold Indyref for a generation or even for Nicola Sturgeonrsquos letime.He told the BBC Scotlandrsquos Sunday Politics that position would not change eventhe SNP repeated their electoral feat of  and won a second Holyrood majority in .He said: ldquoWe do not think that  is the time to start having more referendums.This is a U-turn on his publicly stated position in November, when he said an SNP majority in  would constitute a ldquodemocratic mandate for Indyref negotiations.Mr Jack also said it was ldquounacceptable for Holyrood to have permanent referendum powers, as it would plunge Scotland into a series of constitutional ldquoneverendums.He said he had advised Mr Johnson to deliver a ldquorebuttal to Ms Sturgeon, something she herself has said she expects.THe SNP said his flip-flopping on the issue was "embarrassing".In the wake of the SNPrsquos general election gains last month, Ms Sturgeon has insisted she has a mandate to hold Indyref later this year in order to revisit the No vote of .However she has also suggested the  Scotland Act could be overhauled to give Holyrood permanent powers to hold constitutional referendums when it chose.The Prime Minister is expected to rebuff both suggestions within days.Mr Jack said: ldquoA Section  order is a constitutional matter. What the SNP have asked for in the letter Nicola Sturgeon has sent is the right to choose when the referendum should be.ldquoWe are standing up for the people who are voting for the Unionist parties.ldquoItrsquos about once in a generation, once in a letime. Thatrsquos what people voted for.ldquoI think that wersquove had  years where Scotlandrsquos been in discussion or having referendums.ldquoIt hasnrsquot done our economy any good. Wersquore slower than the English economy. Itrsquos not good for jobs.Pressed on whether Mr Johnson would refuse to give the Scottish Government a Section  order eventhe SNP won an absolute majority on a manesto promise of Indyref, Mr Jack said: ldquoConstitutionally we are coming out of the European Union. Letrsquos seethe worldrsquos still spinning on the st of February and how things can be good for Scotland.Askedhis message to Nicola Sturgeonrsquos was that her successor or successorrsquos successor would have to wait for Indyref, he said: ldquoYeah, a generation or a letime has passed. Letrsquos see the benefits of Brexit for the United Kingdom first.On Ms Sturgeonrsquos request for permanent referendum powers, he went on: ldquoThat is unacceptable. Irsquove written to the Prime Minister on this subject this week.ldquoHersquoll be replying very soon to Nicola Sturgeonrsquos letter of the th of December.ldquoItrsquos absolutely the case that constitutional matters are reserved. They must remain with the UK parliament, the same way defence must remain, the same way foreign policy must remain."It would be wrong for us to give the right to the Scottish Parliament to set the referendums and the context and the timings whenever they wanted for the simple reason that Scotland would then be plunged into neverendums, and thatrsquos not good for us, not good for the economy. ldquoAskedthat was what the Prime Minister would tell Ms Sturgeon this week, Mr Jack said: ldquoNicola Sturgeon has said she fully expects a rebuttal from the Prime Minister to her letter.ldquoMy advice to him is certainly to say that.He went on: ldquoWe have a mandate to say No to a second independence referendum because the Edinburgh Agreement [paving the way for the  referendum] was signed in  by Nicola Sturgeon and Alex Salmond."In that agreement it said both parties will uphold the result of the referendum and respect it. Wersquoll see whether or not the Scottish National Party get a majority then.ldquoI mean the Scottish National Party - not in collaboration with other parties, not in any alliances - but a Scottish National Party majority, which is what Ruth Davidson pointed out some months ago.In June last year, Ms Davidson, while still leader of the Scottish Tories, said an outright majority would be needed to begin negotiations on Indyref.She told the BBC: "If she [Ms Sturgeon] puts it in a [Holyrood] manesto that shes going to hold another referendum and she wins a majority outright, then she can negotiate with theUK government in the same way as happened last time.Asked about his previous comment today, Mr Jack ly claimed he had prefixed it with ldquoRuth Davidson has said.He said: ldquoIn that interview, I made it very clear that it was a once in a letime, once in a generation, vote that we had, and I didnrsquot feel a generation or a letime had passed.ldquoI think we have to take  as a campaign for the Conservatives and the other Unionist parties in Scotland to press hard as they can to press the case for the Union.SNP Shadow Scottish Secretary Mhairi Black said Mr Jackrsquos U-turn was ldquoembarrassing.She said: ldquoThe SNP won a landslide victory in last monthrsquos general election - winning % on a mandate for an independence referendum, while the Tories lost more than half their MPs.ldquoThey stood on a  of stopping Scotlandrsquos right to choose and were humiliated at the polls - the Tories have no mandate whatsoever to block Scottish democracy.ldquoWhatever your views on independence, we can all agree that Scotlandrsquos future must be Scotlandrsquos choice ndash not Boris Johnsonrsquos or his cronies.ldquoScotland voted overwhelmingly to remain in the EU and has rejected Brexit at every opportunity. title: issue-day-author-comes-cold-accept-honour
story: Olof Palme The Olof Palme award is named for the Swedish politician and statesman who was assassinated in  - the killer has never been found. The honour is given for actions conducted "in the spirit" of Palme, intended to reward ldquoan outstanding achievement in any of the areas of anti-racism, human rights, international understanding, peace and common security.Past recipients They include the former secretary general of the United Nations, Kofi Annan, in  and Daniel Ellsberg in , the ex-US military analyst and whistleblower, who released the classied Pentagon Papers in relation to the Vietnam War in , and who was the subject of the  Tom Hanks movie, The Post, which covers his battle to publish the documents. Amensty International won in .And now John le Carreacute, whose real name is David Cornwell, is the latest recipient, with prize organisers commending the British author for ldquohis engaging and humanistic opinion-making in literary form regarding the freedom of the inidual and the fundamental issues of mankind.Announcing the award, they added that ldquoattracting world-wide attention, he is constantly urging us to discuss the cynical power games of the major powers, the greed of global corporations, the irresponsible play of corrupt politicians with our health and welfare, the growing spread of international crime, the tension in the Middle East, and the alarming rise of fascism and xenophobia in Europe and the United States of America.Hersquos most famous for Born in  in Dorset, le Carreacutersquos third novel, The Spy Who Came In From The Cold, was published in , and introduced the character of British intelligence agent, George Smiley, for whom he is probably most well-known.Created as the antithesis of James Bond, Smiley has featured in a raft of le Carreacutersquos works, including Tinker, Tailor, Soldier Spy in  and Smileyrsquos People, in , as well as in A Legacy Of Spies in , with most of his work set during the Cold War.The Night Manager A  TV adaptation of his  novel, The Night Manager, starring Hugh Laurie and Tom Hiddleston, was a hit worldwide, produced by his sons Stephen and Simon Cornwell, with a second series afoot.Le Carreacute is still writing He published his th novel, Agent Running In The Field, last year at the age of .He is a former intelligence officer He writes of what he knows, as le Carreacute was an MI officer in the s, transferring to MI in  where he worked in the British Embassy in Bonn.Hersquos a democracy campaigner Le Carreacute uses his novels to speak out against abuses of power, with his targets ranging from arms dealers to politicians. The author, who usually shys away from honours, has finallly accepted one and said he will donate the prize money to Meacutedecins Sans Frontiegraveres.

title: POLITICS WATCH  It s the Andrew Marr Show  starring actor James McAvoy
story: He began yesterdayrsquos show by saying that it looked like ordinary political le had resumed after a frenzied year dealing with Brexit. Not so.ldquoBoris Johnson has a formidable task drawing up a new trade agreement with the EU ahead of him, there is a real royal crisis, while a shattered opposition still havenrsquot managed to regroup, find a new leader and a new way ahead.ldquoApologiesyoursquod hoped it was all going quiet. Itrsquos as wild as ever!As it happened, Marr had a guest who was in every sense a genuine box office draw.The BBCrsquos Sunday show is meant to be the television equivalent of a Sunday newspaper, with lighter material balancing the heavier political fare.Previous arts guests have included the director Sam Mendes, talking about his movie , Scots actor Brian Cox, the musician James Blunt, and the saxophonist Jess Gillam.The arts filling in the politics sandwich yesterday was one James McAvoy. The Glasgow-born actor is earning toasty reviews for his performance as Cyrano de Bergerac at the Playhouse Theatre in London. Directed by Jamie Lloyd and adapted by Martin Crimp, it is a stripped-back version of Rostandrsquos nineteenth century play. It is so back to basics there is no set, no period costumes, no props, and controversially, no large nose for Cyrano.McAvoy was fine with that. Itrsquos not about the nose, he insisted. ldquoIt is described as being hideous, ugly, all these things. It never is. Itrsquos usually a bit bulbous, itrsquos maybe a bit long, but I think there is always somebody out there who would fancy a bit of that.Now, you might think being on a politics show would involve talking about current affairs. It depends on the guest, however. Some are comfortable talking about politics, others steer clear.Anyone tuning in yesterday to hear McAvoyrsquos hot take on indyref,indeed he even has one, would have been disappointed. Perhaps Marr chose not to ask, or McAvoy did not say anything of note. Either way, the subject failed to make an appearance.The liveliest moment came when Marr brought up Martin Scorsesersquos comments about superhero movies. The director of Raging Bull and The Irishman put the CGI cat among the pigeons recently when he said special effects- laden superhero movies were not proper cinema because there was no genuine jeopardy.He told Empire magazine: ldquoHonestly, the closest I can think of them, as well made as they are, with actors doing the best they can under the circumstances, is theme parks. It isnrsquot the cinema of human beings trying to convey emotional, psychological experiences to another human being.Among McAvoyrsquos most famous roles is Charles Xavier in the X-Men movies. His reaction to Scorsesersquos comments ldquoHersquos Martin Scorsese, he can say what he likes. But I would also hope that hersquos watched every single superhero movie. Irsquove watched some of them and they are dross, and Irsquove watched some of them that have moved me to tears, made me really feel and think. Some of them have terried me and scared me in ways that his [Scorsesersquos] movies have never done.With that it was back to the studio and politics as usual. Even here there was an attempt to inject some drama into proceedings. Marrrsquos final guest was Emily Thornberry, the Shadow Foreign Secretary, and one of those hoping to be the new Labour leader.By today, in common with the other candidates, Thornberry must have secured the backing of at least  MPs MEPs to proceed to the next round of the contest. By yesterday she was still short by more than half. Tick tock.Ms Thornberry said she was ldquofairly confident she would get enough votes. She put her slow start in the race down to the party being in a general state of ldquogrief after the disastrous showing in the General Election.Thus far, the Labour leadership contest has been a ldquoprolier than thou contest to see who has the strongest working class roots. In keeping with this, Marr asked Ms Thornberry about her now infamous  tweet in which she posted a picture of a white van outside a house that was draped with St Georgersquos flags. You appeared to be sneering, he said.I wasnt, said Thornberry. ldquoThe truth is I was brought up on a council estate, in a house that looks very similar to [that], my brother was a builder until he had an accident. Irsquove got a sister who is a bus driver. I donrsquot sneer at people hellip I am a successful woman but I have had a struggle getting here.Sounds like the beginnings of a beautul film script. Ah, but who would play Ms Thornberry

mean a shrinking private sector and higher rents.Adrian Sangster, National Lettings Director at Aberdein Considine, said: ldquoScotlandrsquos landlords already feel unfairly targeted after a number of taxation changes, such as the Additional Dwelling Supplement.ldquoTo now also have to wait ten months to secure an eviction and re-let is adding further unacceptable pressure.ldquoThe private rented sector still plays a vital and necessary part in Scotlandrsquos housing mix, due largely to the failure of successive governments to build enough social housing.ldquoBy creating this increasingly hostile investment market for landlords, governments risk driving investors away, and by default cutting the availability of properties for let and driving up average rents.In , to ease pressure on Scotlandrsquos courts, the SNP Government moved all rent and repair issues in private sector housing to a new Housing and Property Chamber Tribunal based in Glasgow.Social housing and rent arrears cases remained in the Sherf Court.It became free to raise actions in the new tribunal, rather than pound in court, but claims for eviction and arrears had to raised separately, whereas they could be combined in court applications.The result was the Tribunal being swamped with cases, with more than  applications last year alone.Freedom of Information requests found the average time from eviction application to the granting of an eviction order was  days, around  days longer than in court.However the eviction process can only begin after three months of rent arrears.There is also a -day notice period required by law, plus two days intimation, around a week for the tribunalrsquos written decision, followed by a -day appeal period.Adding the  days for a charge for removal, the total time rises to  days.Aberdein Considine said that, as a result, a typical eviction application process leaves landlords with several months of unpaid arrears, and unable to re-let their properties for up to nine months.In the worst case to date, one landlord had to wait  days just to secure an eviction order.Aberdein Considine Solicitor Advocate Carly Stewart, who unearthed the figures and has acted for a number of landlords in the Tribunal, said: ldquoThe move to the new tribunal process is a positive one, but understandably any changes will take time to get right.ldquoEven the most average, straightforward application is taking a y period of time to process through the tribunal. The fastest application to date still took  days.ldquoThis needs to be looked at.Despite creating the legislation which gave rise to it, the Scottish Government said the Tribunal was an independent independent judicial body and the Lord President, as the head of the judiciary, was responsible for its operation.A spokesperson said: ldquoMinisters have taken signicant action to increase security and stability for those living in the private rented sector, including protection from unlawful eviction and wrongful terminations.ldquoWe recognise that rent arrears can be a serious concern for landlords and agree that landlords must be able to recover possession of their property when they follow the correct legal procedures for eviction.ldquoHowever, the Scottish Government considers it entirely appropriate that when seeking to evict someone from their home, this should be done following a fair judicial process.

title: councils-demand-fair-budget-snp
story: In a campaign launched today, the council umbrella body Cosla warns more investment is needed in hard-pressed local services ldquobefore it is too late.It accuses SNP ministers of both skimping on their funding and burdening councils with nationally-directed duties.In , only  per cent of council spending was in lsquoprotected areasrsquo such as education and social work.Last year, more than % was in areas protected by central government, forcing councils to find savings in the other %.Cosla said that meant disproportionate cuts in roads, economic planning and culture and leisure.With another poundm ring-fenced in -, it said an extra poundbn of revenue and poundm of capital spending was vital.Cosla president Alison Evison said: ldquoIn recent budgets the Scottish Government has chosen to overlook the essential services that communities rely on day in, day out.ldquoIf we are to truly realise Scotlandrsquos potential then local authorities must receive a fair settlement.The Government said: ldquoThe failure of the UK Government to publish its budget at an earlier time means we do not have clarity on the funding available for our schools, hospitals and other vital public services.ldquoDespite this, we remain focused on introducing a Scottish budget for -
